dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 68-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis, newly-diagnosed liver cirrhosis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypothyroidism, high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion, and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia I. You were admitted to the obstetrics and gynecology service for a planned transvaginal hysterectomy. Can you tell me more about your medical history and any current symptoms you're experiencing?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I don't have any history of significant alcohol use, and my viral hepatitis serologies were negative for hepatitis A, B, and C.
Doctor: I noticed that your ferritin level was 319 ng/ml, which makes hemochromatosis unlikely. Your anti-mitochondrial and anti-smooth muscle cell antibodies were also negative. So, primary biliary cirrhosis and primary sclerosing cholangitis are unlikely in the absence of other clinical findings. We also considered Wilson's disease, but your serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels were normal, and you did not have any psychiatric symptoms.
Patient: Yeah, that's right. I also remember that my α-1 antitrypsin was within normal limits at 193 mg/dl.
Doctor: Based on your medical history, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) seems to be the most probable explanation for your cirrhosis, given that you have type 2 diabetes mellitus, a body mass index (BMI) of 29.83, and hyperlipidemia. However, you've been taking methotrexate for more than 10 years for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, which could also be a contributing factor.
Patient: Hmm, I see. So what happened during my preoperative evaluation?
Doctor: During the evaluation, your resting supine oxygen saturation was noted to be 93%. At that time, you denied any respiratory or cardiac symptoms, so you underwent the transvaginal hysterectomy, which went smoothly with no complications.
Patient: That's good to hear. But I remember feeling short of breath after the surgery.
Doctor: Yes, on postoperative day two, you became dyspneic while walking to the restroom. We also noted a two-gram drop in your hemoglobin level after surgery, which was promptly corrected with two units of packed red blood cells.
Patient: Oh, I see. Did that help with my shortness of breath?
Doctor: Unfortunately, despite the administration of packed red blood cell transfusions, you still experienced hypoxemia with an oxygen saturation of 82% while sitting up and during ambulation. When you tried to ambulate further, you developed perioral cyanosis.
Patient: Oh no, that doesn't sound good. What should I do now, Doctor?
Doctor: We will continue to closely monitor your condition and provide necessary medical support. It's important that you report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. We will work together to ensure your recovery and to manage your various health conditions.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you were referred to our Veterinary Teaching Hospital at CEU Cardenal Herrera University because your French bulldog has a corneal mass on the right eye that has been enlarging over a 2-month period. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. He's a 7-year-old male and had a complete excision of the third eyelid gland 5 years ago.
Doctor: I see. And did he develop any complications after that surgery?
Patient: Yes, he developed keratoconjunctivitis sicca, which we've been controlling with cyclosporine eye drops and artificial tears.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Now, let's proceed with the examination. I noticed an exophytic pink to white gelatinous mass occupying about 70% of the central cornea on his right eye (Fig. a). His dazzle reflex seems inconsistent, and his menace response is negative. I'll perform a fluorescein staining to check for any corneal damage.
Patient: Alright, what did you find?
Doctor: The fluorescein staining was negative. I also conducted a slit lamp biomicroscopy examination, which showed a severe increase in corneal thickness, pigment deposit, and superficial vascularization. The mass seems to be infiltrating the corneal stroma.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We also performed a Schirmer tear test-1 and measured the intraocular pressure by applanation tonometry. Both of these tests were within normal limits. However, we couldn't perform an indirect ophthalmoscopy.
Patient: And what about his left eye?
Doctor: The ophthalmic exam of the left eye was unremarkable, and no abnormalities were observed on the physical examination.
Patient: So, what's the diagnosis for his right eye?
Doctor: At this time, we suspect it may be corneal neoplasia. Other differential diagnoses include granulation tissue and a chronic inflammatory process. To confirm the diagnosis, we performed an excisional superficial keratectomy under general anesthesia.
Patient: What did you find from that procedure?
Doctor: The histological findings were consistent with corneal carcinoma. We proceeded with transconjunctival enucleation to remove the mass.
Patient: And what happens after that?
Doctor: We have fixed the globe, conjunctiva, and nictitant membrane in 10% neutral buffered formalin and submitted it for histopathologic examination. We'll be able to provide more information once we have the results.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate all your help.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient, a 7-year-old male French bulldog, presented with a chief complaint of a corneal mass on the right eye, which has been enlarging over the past 2 months. The dog had a history of complete excision of the third eyelid gland 5 years ago, followed by the development of keratoconjunctivitis sicca, currently managed with cyclosporine eye drops and artificial tears.
O: Physical examination revealed an exophytic pink to white gelatinous mass occupying about 70% of the central cornea on the right eye. The dog displayed an inconsistent dazzle reflex and a negative menace response. Fluorescein staining was negative. Slit lamp biomicroscopy showed increased corneal thickness, pigment deposit, and superficial vascularization with stromal infiltration. Schirmer tear test-1 and intraocular pressure were within normal limits. The left eye and other physical examinations were unremarkable. Histological examination of the excised mass confirmed corneal carcinoma.
A: The primary diagnosis is corneal carcinoma of the right eye. Differential diagnoses considered were granulation tissue and chronic inflammatory process. The prognosis depends on the containment and possible metastasis of the carcinoma.
P: The management included excisional superficial keratectomy followed by transconjunctival enucleation of the right eye under general anesthesia. The excised tissues were preserved in 10% neutral buffered formalin for further histopathologic examination. Follow-up will involve monitoring for any signs of recurrence or metastasis, and managing the keratoconjunctivitis sicca with ongoing cyclosporine and artificial tears. Further consultations with an oncologist may be necessary depending on the histopathologic findings.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see from your history that you have osteoarthritis and hypothyroidism. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, doc. I noticed a rapidly growing lesion near my left eye about 3 weeks ago, and it's been growing ever since. My primary care physician referred me to you.
Doctor: I see. Let's take a look at the lesion. Upon examination, it appears to be a medial orbital mass causing ectropion of the lower eyelid and symptomatic epiphora. We should perform a CT scan of the orbits to further investigate this lesion.
Patient: Alright, doc. What did the CT scan results show?
Doctor: The CT scan showed a 2.0 × 1.6 × 1.0 cm nonenhancing intraorbital soft tissue lesion abutting the nasal lacrimal duct, lateral and inferior to the globe, without definite osseous remodeling. There is no thickening of the lateral rectus muscle or inflammation. There is a moderate lateral displacement of the intraocular structures, but the globe is intact.
Patient: Oh, I see. What's the next step, doc?
Doctor: We performed an anterior orbitotomy with biopsy 4 days after your presentation. The pathology was initially read as positive for intermediate grade epithelioid carcinoma, but after an outside consultation, the diagnosis was edited to epithelioid sarcoma with rhabdoid features (proximal type).
Patient: What does that mean, exactly?
Doctor: Immunohistochemical stains revealed the tumor to be AE1/AE3 strong positive, GATA3 strong positive, vimentin strong positive, EMA focal positive, calponin focal positive, and a series of other markers were negative. This helps us better understand the nature of the tumor.
Patient: Considering my age and the tumor's histology, what are my treatment options?
Doctor: Due to your age and the tumor histology, chemotherapy is not recommended by medical oncology. We completed your staging workup with a soft tissue neck CT, which showed no evidence of abnormal lymph nodes. Additionally, a chest/abdomen/pelvis CT showed no evidence of metastatic disease in your chest, abdomen, or pelvis. Thus, the disease is localized to the left orbit only.
Patient: That's somewhat relieving. What's the plan moving forward?
Doctor: We will closely monitor the lesion and discuss other treatment options with you as needed. It's important to keep an eye on any changes and report them to us immediately.
Patient: Okay, doc. I'll keep a close watch on it and let you know if there are any changes. Thank you for your help.
Doctor: You're welcome. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any concerns or questions in the meantime. Take care.

Immunohistochemical stains were positive for AE1/AE3, GATA3, vimentin, and focally positive for EMA and calponin. Staging workup with neck and chest/abdomen/pelvis CT scans showed no evidence of metastatic disease.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you have a history of multiple periprosthetic infections in your left knee. Can you tell me more about your past medical history?
Patient: Yeah, I have diabetes, obstructive sleep apnea, congestive heart failure, and gastroesophageal reflux disease.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Have you had any surgeries in the past?
Patient: Yes, I had a lumbar spinal fusion and multiple failed revision two-stage TKAs for my knee infection.
Doctor: I see. Are you currently taking any medications for your conditions?
Patient: Yes, I'm taking furosemide, gabapentin, carvedilol, lansoprazole, docusate, and enalapril.
Doctor: Good to know. Do you have any documented history of allergies or complications with anesthesia?
Patient: No, I don't.
Doctor: On the day of your operation, we administered cephalexin 2 mg. When we opened your left knee, we found cloudy fluid, which was sent for culture and sensitivities. We debrided and irrigated the infected cement spacers on your femur and tibia. A tobramycin and vancomycin cement mixture formed the new spacer. Intraoperatively, you had brief episodes of hypotension on induction, requiring 3 pressors.
Patient: Oh, I didn't know that.
Doctor: For the duration of the case, you required intermittent pressure support with a total of phenylephrine 360 mcg, epinephrine 30 mcg, and norepinephrine 36 mcg. After the surgery, you were extubated and transferred to the recovery room in stable condition.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: Your medications postoperatively included celecoxib 200 mg BID and aspirin 325 mg BID, and we continued you on lansoprazole. We also started you on vancomycin 2 g IV every 12 hours and piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375 g IV every 6 hours.
Patient: Okay, got it.
Doctor: The cultures revealed that your joint was infected with Corynebacterium striatum, so we discontinued the IV piperacillin-tazobactam.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: On postoperative day 2, you developed a nonoliguric AKI, and your creatinine levels increased from a baseline of 0.9 mg/dl to 1.5 mg/dl.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your kidney function and adjust your medications accordingly. Please make sure to attend your follow-up appointments and let us know if you experience any new symptoms or worsening of your condition.
Patient: Alright, I'll make sure to do that. Thank you, doctor.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient, with a history of diabetes, obstructive sleep apnea, congestive heart failure, and gastroesophageal reflux disease, reports multiple failed revision two-stage total knee arthroplasties (TKAs) due to periprosthetic infections in the left knee. He has undergone lumbar spinal fusion and is currently on multiple medications including furosemide, gabapentin, carvedilol, lansoprazole, docusate, and enalapril. No allergies or complications with anesthesia are documented.
O: During the recent surgery, cloudy fluid was noted in the left knee, prompting debridement and irrigation. A new spacer formed from a tobramycin and vancomycin cement mixture was placed. Intraoperative findings included brief episodes of hypotension managed with phenylephrine (360 mcg), epinephrine (30 mcg), and norepinephrine (36 mcg). Postoperative medications include celecoxib 200 mg BID, aspirin 325 mg BID, continued lansoprazole, vancomycin 2 g IV every 12 hours, and initially piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375 g IV every 6 hours, which was discontinued following culture results. Cultures identified Corynebacterium striatum. Postoperative day 2 showed an increase in creatinine from 0.9 mg/dl to 1.5 mg/dl, indicating nonoliguric acute kidney injury (AKI).
A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent periprosthetic joint infection (PJI) of the left knee caused by Corynebacterium striatum, complicated by intraoperative hypotension and postoperative nonoliguric AKI. Differential diagnoses could include other sources of infection or complications related to multiple comorbidities.
P: Continue monitoring renal function and adjust medications as necessary. Maintain vancomycin and manage pain with celecoxib and aspirin. Discontinue piperacillin-tazobactam due to specific pathogen sensitivity. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor the infection status and kidney function. Educate the patient on signs of worsening infection or renal function and ensure compliance with the medication regimen.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi, I see that you were admitted after experiencing a sudden thunderclap headache, preceded by an acute loss of consciousness at your home. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. It happened so suddenly.
Doctor: I understand. Were there any past history of hypertension, seizures, drug abuse, trauma, or infection before this incident?
Patient: No, I never had any of those issues.
Doctor: Okay. On admission, our initial clinical examination showed you were unconscious with a GCS score of 10/15, which corresponds to Hunt & Hess classification Grade IV.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious.
Doctor: After we stabilized you, we performed a CT scan, which showed diffuse subarachnoid haemorrhage and a cisternal clot at the interpeduncular cistern. This is classified as Modified Fisher I. We also noticed moderate dilatation of the temporal horns of the lateral ventricle.
Patient: What does that mean, exactly?
Doctor: It means that you had bleeding in the space around your brain and a clot formed in a specific area. The dilatation of the temporal horns indicates some swelling in your brain. We then performed an angiography to further investigate the cause.
Patient: And what did the angiography show?
Doctor: The angiography revealed a ruptured saccular aneurysm of less than 3 mm in diameter, with a neck of 1.5 mm at the origin of your left frontopolar artery. Considering the small size of the aneurysm and its ruptured nature, we decided to manage it conservatively.
Patient: I see. But I heard that it bled again after 2 weeks?
Doctor: Yes, unfortunately, the aneurysm bled once more. We obtained another CT scan, which showed a superior interhemispheric frontal haematoma that had opened to your ventricular system. This was classified as Modified Fisher IV.
Patient: What did you do then?
Doctor: On Day 15 after the second haemorrhage, we performed a coiling procedure. After selectively placing a microcatheter in the left frontopolar artery aneurysm, we completely obliterated it with a single coil, maintaining the distal arterial lumen totally permeable.
Patient: Did the procedure work?
Doctor: Yes, it did. We performed a follow-up magnetic resonant angiogram 6 months after the coil embolization, and it showed stable occlusion.
Patient: That's good to hear. But recently, I had an episode of GTCS. What happened?
Doctor: We performed an immediate CT scan, which showed a chronic infarct in your left frontal lobe. We will continue to monitor your condition and provide any necessary treatment.
Patient: Alright. Thank you for explaining everything to me, doctor.
ground_truth_soap:

O: On admission, the patient was unconscious with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10/15, indicating a Hunt & Hess classification Grade IV. Initial CT scan revealed diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage and a cisternal clot at the interpeduncular cistern, classified as Modified Fisher I, with moderate dilatation of the temporal horns of the lateral ventricle. Angiography showed a ruptured saccular aneurysm of less than 3 mm in diameter at the origin of the left frontopolar artery. A second CT scan after a rebleed showed a superior interhemispheric frontal hematoma opening to the ventricular system, classified as Modified Fisher IV. A follow-up magnetic resonant angiogram 6 months post-coil embolization showed stable occlusion. A recent CT scan indicated a chronic infarct in the left frontal lobe.
A: The primary diagnosis is a ruptured saccular aneurysm of the left frontopolar artery with subsequent subarachnoid hemorrhage and chronic infarct in the left frontal lobe. Differential diagnoses initially included other causes of sudden loss of consciousness and headache, but imaging confirmed the aneurysm and associated complications.
P: The patient underwent successful coil embolization of the aneurysm. Ongoing management includes monitoring neurological status, managing potential complications from the chronic infarct, and addressing any new symptoms such as seizures. Regular follow-up with neurology is recommended to assess the stability of the aneurysm occlusion and manage any long-term neurological effects. Education on recognizing symptoms of potential complications and when to seek immediate care is crucial for the patient.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi, I understand that you're 32 years old and currently at week 22 of your pregnancy. You were admitted to the haematology department with bilateral supraclavicular swelling, diffuse itching, and right shoulder pain. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I've been experiencing these swellings on both sides of my neck, and they've been very itchy. My right shoulder has been hurting a lot too.
Doctor: Alright, we performed an ultrasound imaging and found pathological bilateral supraclavicular enlarged lymph nodes. After a biopsy, we diagnosed you with nodular sclerosis Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious.
Doctor: It is a type of cancer, but don't worry. We will do our best to help you. We also performed a fetal ultrasound screening and it showed that your baby is developing normally.
Patient: That's a relief. What's the plan for my treatment?
Doctor: We decided not to perform a combined fludeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET)/CT scan before delivery due to the risk of radiation exposure during pregnancy. Instead, we used ultrasound and whole-body MRI (WB-MRI) to stage the disease. It showed right cervical, bilateral supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph node involvement without a bulky mass, indicating Stage IIA disease according to Ann Arbor classification.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means the cancer is in the early stages and has not spread extensively. The multidisciplinary team, including haematologists, gynaecologists, radiologists, and neonatologists, decided to start chemotherapy only if clinically necessary. We have been following up with ultrasound, WB-MRI, haematology consults, and gynaecological examinations. We also started therapy with steroid and paracetamol to slow down the progression of the disease and treat your itching and shoulder pain.
Patient: Hmm, okay. And how's my condition now?
Doctor: At pregnancy week 27, WB-MRI demonstrated a slight progression of the disease, seen as an enlargement of the lymph node packages, with the largest in the mediastinum having an axial diameter of 5.4 x 4.5 cm.
Patient: Oh no, what do we do now?
Doctor: Unfortunately, at pregnancy week 29, your clinical conditions got worse, and you presented with coughing, night sweating, numbness, and pain radiating across the shoulder down the arm. An ultrasound examination showed enlargement of a right axillary lymph node and internal jugular vein thrombosis. We treated the thrombosis with enoxaparin, which allowed complete recanalization in just a week. Due to these symptoms and findings, the team decided to start chemotherapy.
Patient: I see. So, what's the next step?
Doctor: We'll perform another WB-MRI to monitor the progression of the disease and ensure the chemotherapy is working effectively. We'll continue with the multidisciplinary follow-up and adjust the treatment plan as necessary to ensure the best possible outcome for both you and your baby.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate all the efforts and care from the team.

O: Ultrasound imaging revealed pathological bilateral supraclavicular enlarged lymph nodes. Biopsy confirmed nodular sclerosis Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL). Fetal ultrasound screening indicates normal development. Whole-body MRI (WB-MRI) staged the disease as Stage IIA, showing right cervical, bilateral supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph node involvement without a bulky mass. At pregnancy week 27, WB-MRI showed slight disease progression. At week 29, symptoms worsened with coughing, night sweating, numbness, and pain radiating across the shoulder down the arm. Ultrasound examination showed enlargement of a right axillary lymph node and internal jugular vein thrombosis. Enoxaparin treatment led to complete recanalization of the thrombosis within a week.
A: The primary diagnosis is nodular sclerosis Hodgkin's lymphoma, Stage IIA. The patient's condition initially managed conservatively due to pregnancy, has shown progression by week 27 and significant worsening by week 29, necessitating the initiation of chemotherapy. Differential diagnoses would consider other types of lymphoma or metastatic cancers, but biopsy results confirm HL.
P: Continue current treatment with chemotherapy while monitoring disease progression through WB-MRI. Maintain multidisciplinary follow-up involving haematologists, gynaecologists, radiologists, and neonatologists to adjust treatment as necessary and ensure optimal outcomes for both patient and fetus. Manage symptoms with ongoing steroid and paracetamol therapy and continue anticoagulation therapy with enoxaparin as needed. Educate the patient about the signs of potential complications and the importance of reporting new symptoms promptly.

Future plans include regular monitoring of the disease progression and adjusting treatment as necessary to optimize outcomes for both the patient and the fetus. Education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and expected outcomes has been provided to the patient and her family. Compliance with the treatment plan and follow-up appointments will be crucial for the management of the disease and the pregnancy.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've presented with a one-month history of epigastric discomfort. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've been having this discomfort in my upper stomach area for the past month. It's been quite bothersome.
Doctor: I understand. We performed a physical examination, and it was unremarkable. However, your laboratory examination showed slightly elevated amylase levels. We conducted an abdominal contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) and found a low-density mass with a diameter of 30 mm at the pancreatic head, with segmental superior mesenteric vein (SMV) attachment. There was neither stenosis nor arteriosclerosis around the celiac axis at that time.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We also performed endoscopic ultrasonography, and a fine-needle biopsy sample showed adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.
Patient: So, it's cancer?
Doctor: Yes, unfortunately. We proceeded with pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) with superior mesenteric vein resection and reconstruction. Additionally, a lymphadenectomy including right half dissection of the lymph nodes was performed without the nerve plexus around the celiac trunk. Intraoperative exploration ruled out latent peritoneal or liver metastasis and showed normal anatomy of the celiac trunk, mesenteric vessels, and related branches.
Patient: How did the surgery go?
Doctor: The duration of the surgery was 549 minutes, and the blood loss was 863 mL. Blood transfusion was not performed. We had to mobilize the pancreatic body more than usual for the pancreaticojejunostomy because it was a hard pancreas.
Patient: What happened after the surgery?
Doctor: On postoperative day 3, your liver function tests were still abnormal, and we found bloody fluids in the drain. An abdominal CT showed a characteristic hook-pattern on the anterior proximal celiac axis from compression of the MAL, which had not been detected in the preoperative CT. Ischemic changes in the remnant pancreas, hepatic lateral segment, and gastrojejunostomy site were also observed.
Patient: Oh no, what does that mean?
Doctor: Although all celiac branches were visible, there were almost no pulsations in those branches. We first tried interventional radiology, but the procedure failed due to tight compression against the outside of the celiac axis.
Patient: So, what was the next step?
Doctor: You underwent an urgent re-laparotomy to address the issue. I'll be monitoring your progress closely and provide further instructions based on your recovery.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.

O: Physical examination was unremarkable. Laboratory tests showed slightly elevated amylase levels. Abdominal CT revealed a 30 mm low-density mass at the pancreatic head with attachment to the superior mesenteric vein (SMV), without stenosis or arteriosclerosis around the celiac axis. Endoscopic ultrasonography and fine-needle biopsy confirmed adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. Postoperative findings included abnormal liver function tests and bloody fluids in the drain on day 3. A follow-up CT indicated ischemic changes in the remnant pancreas, hepatic lateral segment, and gastrojejunostomy site, with a hook-pattern on the anterior proximal celiac axis from compression of the median arcuate ligament (MAL).
A: The primary diagnosis is pancreatic adenocarcinoma, complicated by postoperative complications including ischemic changes likely due to MAL compression. Differential diagnosis initially included other causes of epigastric discomfort such as pancreatitis or gastric ulcers, which were ruled out by imaging and biopsy.
P: The patient underwent pancreaticoduodenectomy with SMV resection and lymphadenectomy, followed by an urgent re-laparotomy to address ischemic complications from MAL compression. Ongoing close monitoring and supportive care are necessary. Further interventions may include additional surgical or radiological procedures to relieve MAL compression if symptoms persist or worsen. Education regarding the diagnosis, surgical procedures, potential complications, and recovery expectations has been provided. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any arising complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've had a mass on my anterior abdominal wall for about a year now. It's been gradually increasing in size and causing me discomfort.
Doctor: I see. Have you noticed any changes in the mass or your symptoms during certain times, such as during your menstrual cycle?
Patient: Yes, it gets worse during my menses. The mass seems to get bigger and the pain becomes more intense.
Doctor: Okay, thank you for sharing that. Have you had any surgeries in the past, specifically in the abdominal area?
Patient: I had a caesarean section six years ago, but that's it.
Doctor: Alright. I would like to perform a physical examination to get a better understanding of the mass. 
Patient: Sure, go ahead.
Doctor: *Examines the patient* I can feel a circumscribed mass measuring approximately 6 cms in diameter in the infraumbilical region to the left of the midline. The mobility of the swelling seems to be restricted when you contract your muscles, which may suggest infiltration of the underlying musculoaponeurotic structures.
Patient: What does that mean, exactly?
Doctor: It means the mass may be affecting the muscles and tissues beneath the skin. We will need to conduct some laboratory investigations and a CT scan to get a clearer picture. 
Patient: Okay, let's do it.
*After the tests*
Doctor: The laboratory results are within normal limits, and the CT scan revealed a contrast-enhancing lesion in the subcutaneous tissues, infiltrating the underlying musculoaponeurotic structures. This is highly suggestive of an abdominal wall endometrioma.
Patient: So, what's the next step for me?
Doctor: The best course of action would be surgical resection. We would remove the endometrioma along with a portion of the underlying aponeurosis and rectus abdominis muscle.
Patient: And after that?
Doctor: We will place a polypropylene mesh over the defect created by the resection and fix it to the anterior rectus sheath with nonabsorbable sutures. This will help to reinforce the area and promote healing.
Patient: What can I expect after the surgery?
Doctor: The postoperative course should be uneventful. We will perform a histopathological evaluation of the resected specimen to ensure clear resection margins. Following the procedure, there should be no seroma at the operative site, and you should experience complete relief of symptoms.
Patient: That sounds great. Thank you so much for your help, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out. We're here to help.
ground_truth_soap:

Laboratory tests are within normal limits. CT scan shows a contrast-enhancing lesion in the subcutaneous tissues, infiltrating the underlying musculoaponeurotic structures, suggestive of an abdominal wall endometrioma.
A: Primary diagnosis is abdominal wall endometrioma, likely related to previous surgical history (caesarean section). Differential diagnosis could include other benign or malignant soft tissue tumors, but clinical presentation and imaging are highly suggestive of endometrioma.
P: Plan to proceed with surgical resection of the endometrioma, including a portion of the underlying aponeurosis and rectus abdominis muscle. Post-surgical repair will involve placement of a polypropylene mesh fixed with nonabsorbable sutures. Postoperative care will include histopathological evaluation of the resected specimen to confirm clear margins and ensure no residual disease. The patient is expected to have an uneventful recovery with complete resolution of symptoms. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor healing and address any complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: Yes, I have hypertension, diverticulosis, a bicuspid aortic valve with mild insufficiency, and I use alcohol daily.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. What brings you to the emergency department today?
Patient: I've had hiccups for a week now, along with a few episodes of nonbloody and nonbilious emesis. I don't have chest pain, abdominal pain, or dyspnea.
Doctor: Are you currently taking any medications?
Patient: No, I'm not taking any medications.
Doctor: Have you had any prior history of palpitations, syncope, or seizures?
Patient: No, I don't have any prior history of those.
Doctor: Is there any significant family medical history that I should be aware of?
Patient: There's no known significant family medical history.
Doctor: Alright. Your triage vital signs show a temperature of 36.2°C, blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg, heart rate of 114, respiratory rate of 18, and an oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. The physical examination shows dry mucus membranes, regular heart rate without murmur, soft abdomen, and active hiccups. We'll give you a 1-liter bolus of intravenous normal saline and 25 mg of chlorpromazine (Thorazine) by mouth to help with the hiccups.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
[15-20 minutes later]
Doctor: I'm afraid we've encountered a serious issue. After receiving the chlorpromazine, you went into cardiac arrest. We initiated advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) interventions immediately. Your initial rhythm was ventricular fibrillation, requiring four defibrillations at 200 joules each. We also observed Torsades de pointes and administered 2 grams of intravenous magnesium.
Patient: Oh my, that's concerning.
Doctor: Yes, it is. Your post-arrest ECGs show normal sinus rhythm with a rate of 98-99, but your QTc is between 495-521 ms, which is longer than the normal QTc of <440 ms in men. An arterial blood gas test showed metabolic acidosis with a pH of 7.22 (normal range is 7.38–7.42), a lactate level of 14 mmol/L (normal range is 0.60–2.40), and an ionized calcium level of 1.12 mmol/L (normal range is 1.10–1.33). We'll need to perform a comprehensive metabolic panel to investigate further.
Patient: I understand, please do what's necessary.
Doctor: We'll keep you closely monitored and inform you of any updates. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I really appreciate your help.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about your medical history, especially regarding alcohol and tobacco use?
Patient: I've been using alcohol and tobacco extensively for many years.
Doctor: I see. What brings you in today?
Patient: For the past 2 months, I've had this progressively enlarging, painful ulcerative lesion in the middle of my tongue. It's about 5 cm and has even caused an anterior tongue cleft. I've also had unintentional weight loss, left ear pain, and swelling under my jaw.
Doctor: Hmm, have you noticed any lumps in your neck area?
Patient: Yes, I've felt some non-tender lumps on both sides of my neck.
Doctor: It seems you have bilateral palpable lymphadenopathy in levels I, II, and III. Now, I understand you've had biopsies done before by an otolaryngologist. What were the results?
Patient: They didn't find any cancer, but they saw some reactive inflammatory changes.
Doctor: Okay. We also conducted a positron emission tomography scan, which revealed hypermetabolic lesions in your anterior tongue and lymph nodes, suggesting malignancy. The assessment was a likely T3/4N2cM0 tongue squamous cell carcinoma. We performed a panendoscopy with biopsies and a physical examination under anesthesia for surgical planning. However, the biopsy results again did not show carcinoma but rather granulomatous inflammation without organisms present.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: A multidisciplinary tumor board recommended a rheumatologic workup and an excisional lymph node biopsy. The lymph node biopsy results demonstrated noncaseating granulomatous inflammation with no malignancy, while laboratory results showed markedly elevated angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) levels. These findings suggested an atypical case of sarcoidosis, so we referred you for a pulmonary consultation.
Patient: I remember that. I also developed some red spots on my extremities, palms, soles, and trunk.
Doctor: Yes, your laboratory evaluation demonstrated T pallidum immunoglobulin G antibodies present with a reflex RPR titer of 1:512. We then analyzed the lymph node biopsy sample with immunohistochemistry (IHC), which revealed spirochetes. You were diagnosed with tertiary syphilis and started on doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 30 days due to a severe penicillin allergy.
Patient: How am I doing after the treatment?
Doctor: After receiving treatment, your tongue lesion is healing well, but there is still a persistent anterior tongue cleft. It is important for you to follow up with further laboratory evaluations to monitor your progress.
Patient: Alright, I'll make sure to do that. Thank you, Doctor.

Differential diagnosis initially included tongue squamous cell carcinoma and sarcoidosis, but these were ruled out through biopsies and additional testing. The prognosis is good with appropriate treatment, though monitoring is necessary due to the persistent anterior tongue cleft and potential for relapse or incomplete resolution of symptoms.
P: The patient has been prescribed doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 30 days due to severe penicillin allergy, with the treatment course already underway. dialogue:
Patient: Hi doctor, I've been having some issues lately and I'm not sure what's going on.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Well, I've been experiencing urinary frequency and nocturia for about a month now.
Doctor: I see. Let's discuss your medical history to better understand your situation. I know you have multiple psychiatric conditions, including bipolar disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, oppositional defiant disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, and poor impulse control. What medications are you currently taking?
Patient: I'm taking clonidine 0.1 mg three times daily, guanfacine 4 mg daily, bupropion sustained-release 150 mg daily, quetiapine 200 mg twice daily, and lithium 450 mg three times daily. I started lithium when I was 5 years old.
Doctor: Thank you for that information. About a year prior to your presentation, your lithium level was in the range of 0.9–1.1 mmol/L and your serum creatinine was 0.78 mg/dL, with an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 86 ml/min/1.73 m2 based on the bedside Schwartz formula. We'll need to run some tests to identify any issues.
[After running tests]
Doctor: Your physical examination was unremarkable. Urinalysis revealed a specific gravity of 1.006, a pH of 6.0, but no hematuria or proteinuria. Blood tests showed a lithium level of 1.4 mmol/L, a TSH of 5.09 uIU/mL (normal 0.55–4.78 uIU/mL), a calcium of 11.1 mg/dL (normal 8.6–10.6 mg/dL), and a creatinine of 1.15 mg/dL.
Patient: Is there anything we should do about it?
Doctor: Your primary care physician (PCP) reduced your lithium dose to 450 mg twice daily and initiated levothyroxine for hypothyroidism. One week later, your lithium level reduced to 1.1 mmol/L. However, over the next couple of weeks, your creatinine increased to 1.3 mg/dL.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: Your PCP decided to discontinue the lithium by tapering the dose over the next 3 weeks. Despite a very low lithium level of <0.1 mmol/L four weeks after discontinuation, your serum creatinine continued to increase, prompting a nephrology referral.
Patient: So, what happens now?
Doctor: At your presentation to the nephrology clinic, your physical examination was unremarkable. The nephrologist will further evaluate your condition and determine the best course of action for your treatment.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help in figuring this out.
ground_truth_soap:

The patient has a history of multiple psychiatric conditions including bipolar disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, oppositional defiant disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, and poor impulse control. Medications include clonidine 0.1 mg three times daily, guanfacine 4 mg daily, bupropion sustained-release 150 mg daily, quetiapine 200 mg twice daily, and lithium 450 mg three times daily, started at age 5.
O: Physical examination was unremarkable. Urinalysis showed specific gravity 1.006, pH 6.0, no hematuria or proteinuria. Blood tests revealed lithium level 1.4 mmol/L, TSH 5.09 uIU/mL (normal 0.55–4.78 uIU/mL), calcium 11.1 mg/dL (normal 8.6–10.6 mg/dL), and creatinine 1.15 mg/dL. Previous lithium level was 0.9–1.1 mmol/L, serum creatinine 0.78 mg/dL, eGFR 86 ml/min/1.73 m2. After dose adjustment and initiation of levothyroxine, lithium level reduced to 1.1 mmol/L, but creatinine increased to 1.3 mg/dL.

Differential diagnosis includes primary hyperparathyroidism. The increase in creatinine levels despite discontinuation of lithium suggests ongoing renal impairment.
P: The primary care physician reduced lithium dose to 450 mg twice daily and initiated levothyroxine for hypothyroidism. Lithium was tapered off over 3 weeks due to persistent renal function decline. dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I heard you presented to another institution with persistent left chest pain for 8 days. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I've had this left chest pain for more than a week now. It gets more severe when I take a deep breath. I don't have any other complaints though.
Doctor: Do you have any history of recent surgery, deep venous thrombosis, or taking oral contraceptives? How about alcohol consumption or smoking cigarettes?
Patient: No, I don't have any of that history, and I don't drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes.
Doctor: I see. At the other institution, they performed a chest computed tomography (CT) scan which showed scattered small ground-glass opacities in the bilateral lung field and a well-defined dense shadow in the left lung (Fig. A, B). A chest ultrasound confirmed left pleural effusion. You were diagnosed with double pneumonia and left pleural effusion. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And you received antibiotics for 8 days, which slightly alleviated the left chest pain. Then you were transferred to our hospital for further diagnosis and treatment. On admission, your clinical parameters were body temperature 36.5°C, pulse 71 beats/min, respiratory rate 15 breaths/min, blood pressure 118/85 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation when breathing room air 98%. Your physical examination was unremarkable, and your white blood cell count, liver function, kidney function, myocardial markers, and brain natriuretic peptide values were normal. Your D-dimer level was 0.02 mg/L. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's all correct.
Doctor: We performed a repeat chest CT scan on the first day after admission, which showed scattered small ground-glass opacities in the bilateral lung field, but no pleural effusion in the left lung (Fig. C, D). Your ECG revealed sinus rhythm and ST-T wave changes, and myocardial ischemia was suspected. Echocardiography showed that your ejection fraction was 77%, the right ventricle end-diastolic diameter was 23 mm, tricuspid valve regurgitation, and a valve area of approximately 2.0 cm2. Abdominal ultrasound showed no abnormalities of the liver, gallbladder, pancreas, spleen, or kidney. Based on these findings, we suspected double pneumonia and prescribed another course of antibiotics. How have you been feeling since then?
Patient: After two days of antibiotics, my left chest pain was alleviated, but then a similar but more severe pain appeared.
Doctor: I see. We will continue to monitor your condition and adjust your treatment as necessary. Please make sure to follow up with us regularly and let us know if there are any changes in your symptoms or if you have any concerns. It's important to complete the prescribed course of antibiotics and follow any additional instructions we provide.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and will follow your advice.
ground_truth_soap:

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I ruptured my left Achilles tendon while playing soccer in June 2017 and had a tendon repair. But it re-ruptured after a month and an anastomosis procedure was done.
Doctor: I see. How did the anastomosis procedure go?
Patient: Unfortunately, it failed due to a local infection and skin necrosis.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. We can perform reconstructive surgery to address this issue. When did you first experience the initial injury?
Patient: It was 39 days ago.
Doctor: Alright. We've identified Staphylococcus aureus in your bacterial culture results, so we've been giving you a drip infusion of 1g of cefazolin twice a day after hospitalisation until 3 days after the surgery.
Patient: Okay, that's good to know.
Doctor: We've planned a simultaneous reconstruction of your tendon and soft tissue defects using an anterolateral thigh (ALT) and tensor fasciae latae (TFL) muscle chimeric flap, as well as Achilles tendon reconstruction using a TFL flap.
Patient: Hmm, I see.
Doctor: Surgical repair was performed 55 days after the primary rupture. We identified and marked the cutaneous perforator of the ALT flap on your skin preoperatively with a colour Doppler ultrasonography before the operation.
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: During the operation, we performed a wide debridement which resulted in a large combined Achilles tendon, 7 cm long, and overlying skin defect measuring 5.5 × 11 cm.
Patient: Oh, I didn't realize it was that big.
Doctor: Yes, it was quite significant. We elevated an ALT flap with a 6.5 × 13 cm skin island without fascia and a TFL musculofascial flap with an 11-cm length of iliotibial fascia from your right thigh.
Patient: Got it.
Doctor: In your case, the descending branch of the lateral circumflex femoral artery (LCFA), the pedicle of the ALT flap, branched directly from the deep femoral artery or common femoral artery. As a result, the vascular pedicles of the ALT and TFL flaps were independent of each other.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: We then anastomosed the descending branch of the LCFA with the posterior tibialis vessels in an end-to-side fashion first, while the vascular pedicle of the TFL flap was anastomosed with the side branch of the descending branch of the LCFA in an end-to-end fashion.
Patient: I see. So, what are the next steps for me?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your recovery, and you will need to follow up with us regularly to ensure proper healing. In the meantime, take care of the surgical site, follow any prescribed medications, and avoid strenuous activities that may strain the repaired area.
Patient: Alright, thank you so much for your help, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any concerns or notice any unusual symptoms, don't hesitate to contact us. Take care and good luck with your recovery.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient reports a history of left Achilles tendon rupture initially occurring in June 2017, with subsequent re-rupture and failed repair attempts due to infection and skin necrosis. The patient experienced the initial injury 39 days ago and has been under treatment for a Staphylococcus aureus infection.
O: The patient has been receiving 1g of cefazolin twice daily via drip infusion. Surgical intervention included the use of an anterolateral thigh (ALT) and tensor fasciae latae (TFL) muscle chimeric flap for simultaneous reconstruction of the tendon and soft tissue defects. The defect measured 7 cm in tendon length and 5.5 × 11 cm in skin. The ALT flap used was 6.5 × 13 cm, and the TFL musculofascial flap included an 11-cm length of iliotibial fascia. Vascular anastomosis was performed between the descending branch of the lateral circumflex femoral artery and the posterior tibialis vessels, as well as between the vascular pedicle of the TFL flap and the side branch of the descending branch of the LCFA.
A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent rupture of the left Achilles tendon complicated by infection and significant tissue loss. The differential diagnosis would include chronic infection or non-healing due to underlying vascular or systemic issues. The prognosis depends on the success of the reconstructive surgery and the management of the infection.
P: The patient will continue post-operative care including monitoring of the surgical site and infection status. Regular follow-ups are necessary to assess healing and function. The patient is advised to avoid strenuous activities that may strain the repaired area and to adhere to prescribed medications. Further interventions may be considered if complications arise or healing is inadequate.

Doctor: Hi there, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, my 7.5-year-old son has been having progressive gait disturbance and falls lately.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about his history, such as his birth and developmental milestones?
Patient: He had a full-term birth with no pregnancy or delivery complications. He was sitting up without support, walking, and speaking all within the normal range. There is a family history of tremors in his grandfather, though.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Has your son been seen by a pediatric neurologist before?
Patient: Yes, he was first seen at the age of 3.5 years for unsteady gait and toe walking. The gait unsteadiness started around 2.5 years old, and he had frequent falls back then too. Tremors in his hands were noted sometime before that clinic visit.
Doctor: Okay. Can you tell me more about the examination findings at that time?
Patient: The examination showed that he was a well-developed child with a normal funduscopic exam, no cardiac murmur, and normal mental status including speech. He had normal cranial nerves and strength. His deep tendon reflexes were 1+ in both upper and lower extremities with down going toes. His gait was wide based and unsteady, and he had a tremor in both hands.
Doctor: Thank you. Has there been any progression in his condition since then?
Patient: Yes, by the age of 6.5 years, he had more falls and worsening handwriting. His examination revealed pes cavus, mild scoliosis, and absence of cardiac murmur. His neurological exam showed trace to absent deep tendon reflexes, loss of position sense, positive Romberg, downgoing toes, slowed rapid alternating movements, tremor on finger to nose exam, and wide based unsteady gait.
Doctor: I see. Has there been any further progression since then?
Patient: Yes, at 7 years old, he had more frequent falls and worsening handwriting. The examination showed progression with respect to ataxia in upper and lower limbs, wider based gait, absent deep tendon reflexes, and a positive Babinski sign.
Doctor: How is he doing now, around the age of 7.5 years?
Patient: He's falling more, and the latest examination showed increased tone in his lower extremities with foot drop and steppage gait. He also has decreased proprioception in the lower extremities and inconsistent responses in the upper extremities.
Doctor: Thank you for providing all the details. Has he had any imaging done, such as magnetic resonance imaging of the brain?
Patient: Yes, he had an MRI of the brain, and it came back normal.
Doctor: Alright. Based on the information you've provided, it's important to continue monitoring his condition and follow up with his pediatric neurologist. They will be able to advise on potential treatment options and any necessary adjustments to his care. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I'm Dr. Smith. I see you've been admitted to the Emergency Department due to agitation and an altered consciousness. Can you tell me when these symptoms started?
Patient: Hey, doctor. They started just a few hours ago, and I've been feeling a progressive loss of verbal contact.
Doctor: I understand. Your medical history shows that you have arterial hypertension, which is treated with atenolol. When you were admitted, your Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) was 9/15 with moderate neck stiffness. Your pupils were mid-size, reactive, and symmetric. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Your vital signs showed a body temperature of 36.6°C, arterial blood pressure of 180/95 mm Hg, heart rate of 120/min, and respiratory rate of 60/min. We performed a brain computed tomography (CT) without iodinated contrast agent perfusion before the lumbar puncture, and it didn't reveal any significant abnormalities. Due to your progressive respiratory distress, intubation was required. 
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We also conducted a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis, which showed a white blood cell (WBC) count of 560/μl, with 99% granulocytes, proteins at 1264 mg/dl, glucose at 3 mg/dl, and lactate at 27 mmol/l.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: The CSF and blood cultures tested positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is sensitive to penicillin G and ceftriaxone. The minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) was 0.016 mcg/ml for penicillin G and ceftriaxone in the CSF, and 0.012 and 0.008 mcg/ml in blood for penicillin G and ceftriaxone, respectively.
Patient: So, what's the treatment plan?
Doctor: We've started you on a combination of dexamethasone (10 mg q6h for 4 days) and ceftriaxone (2 g q12h for 14 days). After 10 days, we'll repeat the CSF analysis to confirm the drop in WBC count and eradication of the causative microorganism.
Patient: Alright, thank you.
Doctor: However, I have to inform you that you've been referred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to the worsening of your GCS score, which is now 6/15. Even though there's no evidence of acute hydrocephalus, we'll be monitoring your intracranial pressure (ICP).
Patient: I understand, doctor. Thank you for letting me know.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll do our best to help you recover. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

Brain CT showed no significant abnormalities. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis revealed a WBC count of 560/μl with 99% granulocytes, proteins at 1264 mg/dl, glucose at 3 mg/dl, and lactate at 27 mmol/l. CSF and blood cultures tested positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae, sensitive to penicillin G and ceftriaxone. The patient required intubation due to progressive respiratory distress.
A: The primary diagnosis is bacterial meningitis due to Streptococcus pneumoniae, complicated by severe sepsis and respiratory distress. Differential diagnoses could include viral encephalitis or other forms of bacterial meningitis, but these are less likely given the CSF findings and culture results.
P: The patient has been started on dexamethasone 10 mg every 6 hours for 4 days and ceftriaxone 2 g every 12 hours for 14 days. A repeat CSF analysis is scheduled in 10 days to monitor treatment efficacy. The patient has been referred to the ICU for close monitoring of intracranial pressure and further management of GCS deterioration and respiratory distress. Doctor: Hello, I see that you're here today with a chief complaint of nausea, vomiting, lethargy, and decreased level of consciousness. Can you tell me more about these symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I've been feeling really nauseous and tired lately, and sometimes it's hard for me to stay awake or focused.
Doctor: I understand. Let me give you a brief overview of your medical history. You were referred to the Neurology Department of Namazi Hospital in 2016. You were delivered through cesarean section due to oligohydramnios, with a birth weight of 2700 grams and body length of 48 cm. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: You also have a short neck and trunk, pectus carinatum, and kyphosis. The first problem you experienced was at five months of age when growth retardation was detected in a routine workup. Your dental age was also delayed compared to your chronological age. Do you recall that?
Patient: Yeah, I remember my parents telling me about that.
Doctor: Additionally, a bone survey showed delayed bone age, J-shaped sella, periarticular and diffused osteopenia, and flattening of thoracic vertebrae. At 11 months old, you developed a urinary tract infection, and a voiding cystourethrogram diagnosed bilateral vesicoureteral reflux. Your kidneys, ureters, and urinary bladder ultrasonography, as well as renal scintigraphy, were normal. Can you confirm this?
Patient: Yes, that sounds right.
Doctor: When you were 4 years old, a urine analysis showed proteinuria for the first time, and after more workups, nephrotic syndrome was confirmed. Did you have any new problems after that?
Patient: No, not until I was 6 years old.
Doctor: At the age of 6, you developed sudden onset right upper extremity paresthesia and weakness. A brain MRI showed ischemic and hemorrhagic infarct in the left parieto-occipital and left caudate lobe. Brain Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) revealed significant wall irregularity of both internal carotid arteries, left Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA), basilar artery, and left Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA). Your MRI of the cervical spine was normal. Can you tell me more about those symptoms?
Patient: I remember feeling sudden tingling and weakness in my right arm around that time.
Doctor: Two years later, you developed slurred speech and paresthesia, and the weakness progressed to your lower extremities. A brain MRI revealed new acute ischemic infarction in the right temporoparietal lobe. Encephalomalacia with surrounding gliosis was also detected. How have these symptoms affected you?
Patient: It's been difficult. My speech got worse, and the tingling and weakness spread to my legs.
Doctor: I understand that this must be very challenging for you. We will continue to monitor and manage your symptoms. It's important to keep up with your follow-up appointments and to let us know if you experience any new or worsening symptoms.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to contact us. Take care.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. How can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I was diagnosed with rectal adenocarcinoma back in 2013. I had a biopsy done after an endoscopic control examination. I was treated with radio adjuvant chemotherapy and surgery. I'm here for a follow-up appointment.
Doctor: I see. How have you been feeling since your treatments?
Patient: I've been feeling pretty good, actually. The combination of treatments led to a complete response, and there were no residual cancer areas or lymph node involvement documented on the surgical piece.
Doctor: That's great to hear. Let's discuss your recent check-up. In 2018, during your regular oncological follow-up, a subpleural pulmonary nodule was detected in the lower lobe of your left lung. It measured about 15x10 mm. Considering your clinical history, general conditions, and the localization of the lesion, a surgical resection of the lung was performed. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, I do.
Doctor: On the macroscopic exam of the sample, physicians observed a neoformation measuring 1.9x1.5x0.6 cm, which was whitish, solid, with irregular but well-defined margins. It was 0.6 cm away from the surgical suture and 0.1 cm from the visceral pleura. The histologic examination demonstrated an epitheliomorphic neoplasm with acinar differentiation.
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?
Doctor: It means that the tumor cells were positive for cytokeratin 20 (CK20) and had scattered positivity for caudal type homeobox 2 (CDX2). They were also strongly and diffusely positive for TTF-1. However, the tumor cells were negative for CK7 and Napsin A. A retrospective review of your previous primary tumor tissue showed similar histologic findings with TTF-1 positivity.
Patient: So, what's the diagnosis?
Doctor: Based on the positivity for CK20 and CDX2, and the negative results for CK7 and Napsin A, along with the morphology of the lesion, the diagnosis is metastasis from TTF1-positive primary colorectal adenocarcinoma.
Patient: Oh, I see. What should I do next?
Doctor: We will need to closely monitor your condition and discuss appropriate treatment options with your oncologist. Regular follow-up appointments will be necessary to ensure the best possible outcome.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any more questions or concerns. Take care, and we'll see you at your next appointment.

A: The diagnosis is metastasis from TTF1-positive primary colorectal adenocarcinoma, based on the histologic similarity to the primary tumor and immunohistochemical profile. The prognosis depends on the extent of metastasis and response to further treatment.
P: The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and regular follow-up appointments with the oncologist to discuss treatment options. Emphasis will be placed on surveillance imaging and possibly systemic therapy, depending on the progression of the metastasis and overall health status of the patient.

Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about your medical history? 
Patient: I don't have any medical history, but I've been having trouble swallowing lately.
Doctor: I see. We performed an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and found type III esophageal cancer in the middle thoracic esophagus, and type II gastric cancer in the cardia. A computed tomography (CT) scan also revealed a left renal tumor and multiple swollen lymph nodes in your neck, mediastinum, and abdomen, including the left renal hilar and para-aortic regions.
Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, based on these findings, you have been diagnosed with multiple primary cancers of the esophagus (T3N3M0), stomach (T2N1M0), and kidney (T1bN1M0), according to the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) 7th edition.
Patient: What's the treatment plan for this?
Doctor: We started with two cycles of neoadjuvant chemotherapy using nedaplatin and 5-fluorouracil. Then, we performed a two-stage operation to decrease the surgical stress. The first-stage operation involved preoperative percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube placement, followed by thoracoscopic subtotal esophagectomy in the prone position, and cervical esophagostomy placement with mediastinal and cervical lymphadenectomy.
Patient: How did the operation go?
Doctor: The operation was uneventful. It involved 29 mL of blood loss and took 284 minutes to complete. We started gastrostomy feeding on postoperative day (POD) 3 with a polymeric formula at a rate of 20 mL/h for 15 hours per day, increasing the rate to 40, 60, and 80 mL/h for 15 hours per day on POD 5, 6, and 7, respectively.
Patient: I remember that. But on POD 7, I developed diarrhea and acute abdominal pain with distension and bloody drainage through the gastrostomy tube.
Doctor: Yes, when we examined you, your temperature was 37.2 °C, but your other vital signs were normal. Your abdomen was distended with mild diffuse tenderness, but there was no guarding or rigidity.
Patient: What were the results of the laboratory evaluation?
Doctor: Your laboratory evaluation showed an elevated white blood cell count of 11.9 × 109/L and a C-reactive protein level of 59.0 mg/L. Arterial blood gas analysis showed no signs of metabolic acidosis.
Patient: What are the next steps for my treatment and recovery?
Doctor: Our team will closely monitor your condition and manage your symptoms. We will discuss any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan and provide guidance on follow-up requirements. Please keep us informed about any changes in your symptoms or if you have any concerns.

Vital signs were stable except for a temperature of 37.2 °C. Lab results showed elevated WBC at 11.9 × 10^9/L and CRP at 59.0 mg/L. No metabolic acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I see that you've presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of right arm and leg weakness that started around 3 hours prior to admission. Can you tell me more about your recent health?
Patient: Yeah, I had a viral illness about 5 days ago. I felt really tired, had a fever, and even vomited and had diarrhea.
Doctor: I see. Were you seen by a pediatrician during that time?
Patient: Yes, they said I had mild dehydration and suggested oral rehydration and antipyretics for my fever.
Doctor: That's a good course of action. And are your immunizations up-to-date?
Patient: Yes, they are.
Doctor: Great. Upon arrival, we did a physical exam and noticed flaccidity in your right upper and lower extremities. We also took X-rays of your right arm to rule out any trauma, but the results were negative. 
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: Additionally, we found that you have microcytic anemia with a hemoglobin level of 6 g/dL, and thrombocytosis, with a platelet count of 512,000. 
Patient: Oh, what does that mean?
Doctor: It means that your red blood cells are smaller than normal, and you have an increased number of platelets in your blood. We also performed a computed tomography (CT) scan of your head without contrast, which showed hypodensity of the left thalamus and high attenuation throughout the bilateral deep venous system, compatible with acute DCVT.
Patient: That sounds serious.
Doctor: It is a concerning finding, but we've already initiated anticoagulation therapy and IV hydration to address the issue. After discussing the radiologic findings with the ED physician, we decided to transfer you to the Intensive Care Unit of our tertiary pediatric hospital.
Patient: What will happen there?
Doctor: We'll perform a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of your brain, which will help us assess the extent of the issue. The MRI demonstrated restricted diffusion in the central aspect of the thalamus, surrounded by vasogenic edema, indicating an acute venous infarction. Thankfully, no other parenchymal lesions were detected. 
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: We also conducted an MR venography, which confirmed a lack of flow-related signal throughout the deep venous system. You'll have a follow-up MR venography done two days later before discharge. At that time, there was no significant interval change, but we did find a relatively stable venous infarct in the left thalamus and posterior limb of the internal capsule.
Patient: Will I recover from this?
Doctor: Your symptoms resolved completely after six months of physical and speech therapy, with no residual symptoms. You'll be closely followed by pediatric neurology to ensure your continued recovery.
Patient: I'm glad to hear that. Thank you, doctor.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient, a pediatric individual, presented with sudden onset of right arm and leg weakness approximately 3 hours prior to admission. The patient reported a recent viral illness characterized by fatigue, fever, vomiting, and diarrhea approximately 5 days ago, treated with oral rehydration and antipyretics. The patient confirmed that immunizations are up-to-date.
O: Physical examination revealed flaccidity in the right upper and lower extremities. X-rays of the right arm were negative for trauma. Lab results indicated microcytic anemia with a hemoglobin level of 6 g/dL (normal: 12-16 g/dL) and thrombocytosis with a platelet count of 512,000 (normal: 150,000-450,000). A CT scan of the head showed hypodensity of the left thalamus and high attenuation in the bilateral deep venous system, suggestive of acute deep cerebral venous thrombosis (DCVT). MRI of the brain demonstrated restricted diffusion in the central aspect of the thalamus with surrounding vasogenic edema, indicative of acute venous infarction, and MR venography confirmed lack of flow-related signal in the deep venous system.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute deep cerebral venous thrombosis with resultant venous infarction in the left thalamus and posterior limb of the internal capsule. Differential diagnoses initially included trauma and other causes of acute limb weakness, which were ruled out by imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the complete resolution of symptoms after six months of therapy, though ongoing monitoring is essential.
P: The patient was initiated on anticoagulation therapy and IV hydration upon diagnosis. Management included transfer to a tertiary pediatric hospital's ICU for further care, including advanced imaging and specialist consultation. The patient underwent physical and speech therapy, resulting in complete resolution of symptoms. Follow-up care includes ongoing monitoring by pediatric neurology to ensure no recurrence or residual effects. Further MR venography was scheduled to monitor the stability of the venous infarct. Compliance with anticoagulation therapy and follow-up appointments is crucial for recovery and prevention of complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been experiencing some gradually progressing weakness in my right arm.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your medical history? Any notable illnesses or conditions?
Patient: I had asthma when I was a child, but that's about it. No family history of anything major.
Doctor: Alright. Let's do a physical examination to check for any abnormalities. *examines patient* I see some mild paralysis in your right arm. Have you been experiencing any other symptoms, like palpitations or sweating?
Patient: Yes, I do feel palpitations and sweating sometimes.
Doctor: Alright. I'm not observing any exophthalmic or enlarged thyroid lobes. We'll need to conduct some tests to understand your condition better. We'll start with diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA).
*After the tests*
Doctor: Your DWI results showed cortical and subcortical infarcts in the left MCA territory, but your MRA showed almost normal cerebral arteries with very mild stenosis of the left ICA. The vessel wall in the left ICA seems slightly thicker than the right, but the difference isn't very clear.
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?
Doctor: We've identified hyperthyroidism in your blood test results. Your levels of free T3, free T4, and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) are 10.58 pg/mL, 2.70 ng/dL, and 0.01 μU/mL, respectively. Additionally, we found autoantibodies related to Graves' Disease, such as anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody (anti-TPO Ab, 148.0 IU/mL) and TSH receptor antibody (TRAb, 8.3 IU/mL).
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: Other laboratory investigations showed leukopenia, anti-SS-A antibody (89.5 IU/mL), anti-SS-B antibody (12.4 IU/mL), and thrombin-antithrombin complex (TAT, 2.5 ng/mL). Your C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) were negative.
Patient: Is that something to be concerned about?
Doctor: Based on these results, we've diagnosed you with Graves' Disease, but not Sjogren's syndrome, as the normal results of Schirmer's test and unstimulated salivary flow rate test ruled it out.
Patient: I see. What's the next step?
Doctor: We'll need to start treatment for your Graves' Disease and monitor your progress. I'll also want you to come back for regular checkups to ensure your symptoms improve and your thyroid hormone levels return to normal.
Patient: Alright, thank you, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any concerns or questions, don't hesitate to reach out. Take care!
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient reports gradually progressing weakness in the right arm, accompanied by occasional palpitations and sweating. The patient has a history of childhood asthma but no significant family medical history.
O: Physical examination revealed mild paralysis in the right arm. Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) indicated cortical and subcortical infarcts in the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) showed almost normal cerebral arteries with very mild stenosis of the left internal carotid artery (ICA) and slightly thicker vessel walls compared to the right. Blood tests confirmed hyperthyroidism with elevated free T3 (10.58 pg/mL, normal range: 2.0-4.4 pg/mL), free T4 (2.70 ng/dL, normal range: 0.9-1.7 ng/dL), and suppressed TSH (0.01 μU/mL, normal range: 0.4-4.0 μU/mL). Positive autoantibodies related to Graves' Disease were detected: anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody (anti-TPO Ab, 148.0 IU/mL) and TSH receptor antibody (TRAb, 8.3 IU/mL). Other laboratory findings included leukopenia, anti-SS-A antibody (89.5 IU/mL), anti-SS-B antibody (12.4 IU/mL), and thrombin-antithrombin complex (TAT, 2.5 ng/mL). C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) were negative. Schirmer's test and unstimulated salivary flow rate test ruled out Sjogren's syndrome.
A: Primary diagnosis of Graves' Disease based on clinical symptoms, imaging, and laboratory findings. Differential diagnosis included cerebrovascular ischemia due to infarcts in the left MCA territory, but no significant stenosis or vessel wall abnormalities were observed to confirm a vascular cause. The presence of leukopenia and positive anti-SS-A and anti-SS-B antibodies raised a suspicion for an autoimmune disorder, but Sjogren's syndrome was ruled out.
P: Initiate treatment for Graves' Disease with appropriate anti-thyroid medications and possibly beta-blockers to manage symptoms. Regular monitoring of thyroid function tests and adjustment of therapy as needed. Follow-up appointments for physical examination and repeat imaging studies to monitor progression or resolution of cerebral infarcts. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and symptom monitoring. Provide contact information for any questions or concerns regarding treatment or symptoms.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, can you tell me about the accident you had back in 1995?
Patient: Yes, I was 25 years old and riding my bicycle to work when I collided with a van parked on the bicycle lane.
Doctor: I see. And after that accident, you were diagnosed with a C-6/C-7 dislocation and C-8 AIS A tetraplegia, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: How have you been managing your bladder since your rehabilitation?
Patient: My caregivers have been helping me with intermittent catheterisations and intra-vesical instillation of oxybutynin 5 mg solution, four times a day.
Doctor: Have you experienced any issues with your bladder recently?
Patient: Yes, in 2014, I started having recurring bladder spasms and urine leakages between intermittent catheterisations.
Doctor: And were you able to retain the oxybutynin instillations?
Patient: No, the solution would come out as soon as it went inside the bladder.
Doctor: Did you experience any other symptoms during that time?
Patient: I had symptoms of autonomic dysreflexia like blotches on my legs, sharp pain in my head, hot feeling on my face, and bladder pain with spasms.
Doctor: Were those symptoms relieved after catheterisation?
Patient: The blotches went away, and my headache was relieved, but the warm sensation and bladder pain persisted.
Doctor: I understand that you were prescribed mirabegron 50 mg once a day from June 2014 to January 2015. Did that help with your urine leakages?
Patient: No, it made no difference.
Doctor: And then you were prescribed oxybutynin by mouth and transdermal application from January 2015, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: You've also been taking oral baclofen since 1995. Did that have any effect on your bladder spasms?
Patient: No, but it did reduce spasms in my back and legs.
Doctor: How often have you needed to catheterise lately?
Patient: Every couple of hours.
Doctor: And how has this affected your quality of life?
Patient: It's been difficult to cope with physically and mentally. I don't want to live with a permanent catheter and urine bag.
Doctor: Have you tried using a permanent catheter for social occasions?
Patient: Yes, but sometimes I would still bypass.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient, a 51-year-old with a history of C-6/C-7 dislocation and C-8 AIS A tetraplegia from a bicycle accident in 1995, reports managing bladder function with intermittent catheterizations and intra-vesical instillation of oxybutynin 5 mg solution four times daily. Since 2014, the patient has experienced recurring bladder spasms and urine leakages between catheterizations, which have not improved with mirabegron or oral/transdermal oxybutynin. The patient also describes symptoms of autonomic dysreflexia, including blotches on legs, severe headaches, facial heat, and persistent bladder pain. Baclofen has been used since 1995 to manage muscle spasms but has no effect on bladder spasms.
O: The patient's current management includes intermittent catheterization every couple of hours, intra-vesical oxybutynin, and oral baclofen. Previous treatments with mirabegron and additional oxybutynin modalities were ineffective. The patient experiences significant physical and mental challenges due to frequent catheterizations and persistent symptoms.
A: Primary diagnosis is chronic bladder management issues secondary to C-8 AIS A tetraplegia with symptoms of autonomic dysreflexia. Differential diagnoses could include complications from long-term catheter use such as bladder irritation or infection. The lack of response to mirabegron and oxybutynin suggests a complex bladder dysfunction possibly resistant to standard antimuscarinic treatments.
P: Continue current regimen of intermittent catheterization and intra-vesical oxybutynin. Consider consultation with a urologist for evaluation of alternative bladder management strategies, such as botulinum toxin injections or nerve stimulation therapies. Explore options for managing autonomic dysreflexia and its symptoms more effectively. Provide psychological support and counseling to address the patient's mental health concerns related to chronic illness management. Educate the patient on signs of potential complications like urinary tract infections or severe autonomic dysreflexia episodes requiring immediate medical attention.
