dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've been referred to me with a six-month history of medically refractory seizures. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I've been experiencing daily episodic paresthesias with phantosmia, and I also have a right-sided severe to profound mixed hearing loss.
Doctor: I understand. I also noticed in your medical history that you have chronic otitis media and had a right-sided tympanomastoidectomy 20 years prior. Have you been having any issues with your eustachian tube since then?
Patient: Yeah, I've been having ongoing problems with eustachian tube dysfunction.
Doctor: Alright. Have you experienced any CSF rhinorrhea, otorrhea, or other symptoms related to your condition?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those issues.
Doctor: That's good to know. To further investigate your seizures, we've done a seizure workup which included a video EEG. It confirmed that your paresthesias and phantosmia are caused by right temporal lobe epilepsy. We also performed computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans, which demonstrated a right temporal lobe encephalocele.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: In addition to the TLE, the MRI showed increased edema and flair signal within your right mesial temporal lobe. We discussed your case at a multidisciplinary skull base conference, and the decision was made to proceed with a combined mastoid-middle cranial fossa encephalocele repair surgery. Informed consent was obtained from you prior to the surgery.
Patient: Yes, I remember.
Doctor: During the surgery, we repaired a 1 x 1 cm tegmen defect with the herniation of glial tissue into the mastoid. We performed a partial resection and used an Onlay dural substitute to fix the defect. Your postoperative course went smoothly.
Patient: That's good to hear. I did notice an improvement in my seizure frequency and duration after the surgery, but they haven't fully resolved.
Doctor: Yes, we've noticed that as well. A repeat 3T epilepsy protocol MRI showed further hippocampal atrophy, increased flair within the right hippocampus, and the loss of gray-white differentiation in the anterior temporal lobe. This has led us to diagnose you with mesial temporal lobe sclerosis.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: On a retrospective neuroradiology review, we observed the progression of decreased hippocampal volume in your MRIs leading up to the surgery. Currently, we are working on a plan for the resection of the temporal epileptically focal lesion to better manage your condition.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help in figuring out what's going on and working on a solution.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient reports a six-month history of medically refractory seizures, daily episodic paresthesias, phantosmia, and ongoing eustachian tube dysfunction. The patient has a history of chronic otitis media and underwent a right-sided tympanomastoidectomy 20 years ago. No symptoms of CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea were reported.
O: The patient has a right-sided severe to profound mixed hearing loss. Video EEG confirmed right temporal lobe epilepsy. CT and MRI scans revealed a right temporal lobe encephalocele and increased edema and flair signal within the right mesial temporal lobe. Postoperative findings included a repaired 1 x 1 cm tegmen defect with herniation of glial tissue. A repeat 3T epilepsy protocol MRI showed further hippocampal atrophy, increased flair within the right hippocampus, and loss of gray-white differentiation in the anterior temporal lobe.
A: The primary diagnosis is right temporal lobe epilepsy with mesial temporal lobe sclerosis, secondary to a right temporal lobe encephalocele and post-surgical changes. Differential diagnosis includes other causes of refractory seizures, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and history.
P: The management plan includes proceeding with the resection of the temporal epileptically focal lesion to better manage the seizures. Continued monitoring of the patient’s neurological status and seizure frequency will be necessary. Further consultations with neurosurgery and continued follow-up in the epilepsy clinic are recommended. Education regarding seizure management and potential postoperative outcomes will be provided to ensure patient understanding and compliance.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having some pain in my kidney area and my doctor told me I might have a staghorn calculus.
Doctor: I see. Based on your condition, you might need a nephro-ureterostomy stent placement. This procedure will help alleviate your symptoms. We'll use fluoroscopic guidance to accurately place the stent.
Patient: Hmm, how does that work?
Doctor: First, we'll introduce a 21-gauge needle through your skin into an inferior renal calyx. Then, we'll perform an antegrade pyelogram to visualize the opacification of your collecting system.
Patient: Okay, and what happens after that?
Doctor: After demonstrating the return of urine, we'll pass a wire through the needle and introduce a dilator over the wire. We may use multiple catheters and wires to attempt to gain access to the collecting system.
Patient: Alright, and how long does the procedure usually take?
Doctor: It varies for each patient but could take around two hours. In some cases, we might have to abandon the procedure if we can't access the central renal pelvis due to the obstructive staghorn calculus. However, we'll do our best to ensure the procedure is successful.
Patient: I see. What other options do you have if the initial attempts don't work?
Doctor: We could use a SwiftNINJA® SMC catheter from Merit Medical Systems. It's designed to easily navigate around the staghorn calculus and eventually reach the proximal ureter.
Patient: That sounds like a good option.
Doctor: Yes, once we reach the ureter, we'll use a Platinum Plus™ guidewire from Boston Scientific to guide the SMC into the bladder. Then, we'll exchange the SMC for a 4-French Berenstein catheter and place an 8.5-French nephro-ureterostomy stent from Cook Medical.
Patient: And where will the stent be placed?
Doctor: The distal loop of the stent will be formed in your urinary bladder. However, due to the space-occupying staghorn calculus, we might be unable to form the proximal loop in the renal pelvis. But don't worry, we'll inject contrast through the stent to ensure proper flow.

Doctor: You're welcome. We'll schedule the procedure as soon as possible and provide you with all the necessary instructions for preparation and follow-up care.

dialogue:
Doctor: Good morning! I see from your history that you're a 72-year-old female with hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and a 50 pack-year smoking history. Can you please describe the symptoms that brought you here today?
Patient: Good morning, doctor. Over the past 6 months, I've been experiencing a 30-pound weight loss, severe nausea, emesis, mild imbalance which gradually turned into bedbound instability, and involuntary body shakes.
Doctor: I understand that can be very concerning. I see that you've already had some tests done at an outside facility, including contrast-enhanced MRI imaging, EEG, colonoscopy, and basic hematologic and chemistry panels. It seems that all those tests came back normal. However, there were a few abnormal findings. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) showed possible gastritis; your thyroid stimulating hormone was mildly elevated at 9 U/mL, and your anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody was also elevated at 50 mg/L. Did you receive any treatment for these issues?
Patient: Yes, I was evaluated by a psychiatrist who prescribed sertraline and recommended relaxation techniques. But my family wanted me to get further evaluation, so I was transferred to your institution.
Doctor: I'm glad you came to us for further evaluation. During your physical exam here, we noticed disorganized high amplitude conjugate horizontal eye movements that persisted even with eye closure, severe truncal ataxia that prevented you from sitting up without support, and distinct abdominal myoclonus. However, your other neurological exam results, including your mental status, were unremarkable. We started you on symptomatic and empiric therapy with lorazepam, levetiracetam, and a 5-day course of high-dose IV methylprednisolone. How are you feeling now?
Patient: Hmm, I do feel a bit better, but I'm still struggling with some of my symptoms.
Doctor: I understand. We did some additional tests on your cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). It showed a lymphocytic pleocytosis with 25 WBCs, but an otherwise unremarkable profile. Cytology was negative for malignancy, and flow cytometry demonstrated a T cell dominant inflammatory process, believed to be reactive. Your paraneoplastic panel in the CSF was negative; however, we detected voltage-gated potassium channel antibodies (VGKC) in your serum at 0.05 nmol/L, which is above the normal range of <0.02 nmol/L.
Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean for me, doctor?
Doctor: The elevated VGKC antibodies in your serum could be contributing to your symptoms. Unfortunately, we couldn't perform the CSF VGKC assay at our laboratory at the time of your evaluation. We'll continue to monitor your condition and adjust your treatment accordingly. It's important to keep an open line of communication about your symptoms and how you're feeling.
Patient: Okay, I understand. Thank you for explaining everything to me, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any concerns or questions, please don't hesitate to reach out. We're here to help you through this process.
ground_truth_soap:

She has been treated with sertraline and relaxation techniques by a psychiatrist without significant improvement.
O: Physical examination revealed disorganized high amplitude conjugate horizontal eye movements, severe truncal ataxia, and abdominal myoclonus. Neurological examination was otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory tests showed mildly elevated thyroid stimulating hormone at 9 U/mL (normal: 0.4-4.0 U/mL) and elevated anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody at 50 mg/L. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy indicated possible gastritis. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis showed lymphocytic pleocytosis with 25 WBCs and a T cell dominant inflammatory process. Serum voltage-gated potassium channel antibodies were elevated at 0.05 nmol/L (normal: <0.02 nmol/L). Imaging and additional tests including MRI, EEG, and colonoscopy were normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is likely autoimmune encephalitis, suggested by clinical symptoms of severe truncal ataxia, eye movement abnormalities, abdominal myoclonus, and elevated VGKC antibodies. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of encephalitis, central nervous system disorders, or paraneoplastic syndromes, although the paraneoplastic panel was negative.
P: Continue management with lorazepam, levetiracetam, and high-dose IV methylprednisolone. Monitor response to therapy and adjust as necessary. Further evaluation with a repeat CSF VGKC assay when available. Regular follow-up appointments to assess symptom progression and medication side effects. Patient education regarding the nature of autoimmune encephalitis and the importance of medication adherence and follow-up visits. Consider referral to a neurologist specializing in autoimmune disorders for further management and potential immunotherapy.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, welcome to our institution. I understand you've been transferred here due to gastric cancer. Can you tell me about your symptoms and medical history?
Patient: Yes, I've had a history of black stools and anemia for about 3 years now. My past medical history includes multiple comorbidities like diabetes, chronic renal failure, alcoholic cirrhosis Child A, complete heart blockade, and thrombocytopenia of unknown etiology.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. We performed an upper endoscopy and biopsy which revealed a well-differentiated intestinal type adenocarcinoma in the antrum. Endoscopic ultrasonography showed a hypoechoic, 3.2 cm neoplasm, without muscularis externa infiltration and reactive ganglia.
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?
Doctor: It means that we have identified a tumor in your stomach. Given the tumor size, stage, and your comorbidities, we chose endoscopic mucosal resection as the best treatment option. The tumor was fully resected without complications.
Patient: That's a relief. So, what happened after the procedure?
Doctor: During the procedure, the anesthesiologist had difficulty with ventilation and abdominal distention was observed. Your blood pressure was 128/91 mmHg and your heart rate was 70 bpm. We performed an endoscopic revision before finishing the procedure, but we didn't identify any macroscopic perforation.
Patient: So, what did you do next?
Doctor: We placed a nasogastric tube and instituted therapeutic strategies to improve abdominal-wall compliance, such as changes in ventilation parameters, nasogastric suction, changing your position to supine, and removal of any strap over the abdomen. A plain abdominal radiography in the operating room showed a massive pneumoperitoneum.
Patient: What did you decide to do after that?
Doctor: We decided on a nonsurgical management approach and took you to the intensive care unit (ICU) for monitoring. The intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) measured by a trans-bladder catheter was 33 mmHg.
Patient: What happened in the ICU?
Doctor: Six hours after ending the procedure, you developed dyspnea and anuria, leading to a diagnosis of abdominal compartment syndrome. Given your worsening status, interventional radiology evaluated you. A CT scan confirmed the massive pneumoperitoneum without intraperitoneal extravasation of contrast.
Patient: What was the next step in my treatment?
Doctor: We performed a percutaneous decompression guided by CT scan using a pigtail catheter G14. Air was immediately released under pressure, which helped improve your symptoms and hemodynamic status. Diuresis returned after a few hours.
Patient: That sounds like it went well.
Doctor: Yes, the pigtail catheter was closed the first day after placement and taken out on the third postoperative day. Your condition has improved since then, and we will continue to monitor your progress closely.
Patient: Thank you, doctor, for explaining everything and taking good care of me.

Vital signs recorded were blood pressure 128/91 mmHg and heart rate 70 bpm. Post-procedure, a massive pneumoperitoneum was detected on plain abdominal radiography. Intra-abdominal pressure was elevated at 33 mmHg. A CT scan confirmed the pneumoperitoneum without intraperitoneal extravasation of contrast. Percutaneous decompression was performed using a pigtail catheter G14, which improved the patient's symptoms and hemodynamic status.
A: The primary diagnosis is well-differentiated intestinal type adenocarcinoma of the stomach, successfully resected. Complications included abdominal compartment syndrome secondary to massive pneumoperitoneum, managed with percutaneous decompression. The patient's multiple comorbidities complicate the overall management and prognosis.
P: Continue close monitoring in the ICU with supportive care and management of comorbidities. Regular follow-up imaging and labs to monitor for any recurrence of cancer or complications from the procedure. Educate the patient on signs of complications and ensure understanding of the treatment and follow-up plan. Address compliance challenges due to the complexity of the patient's medical history and current condition.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see from your records that you were involved in a dirt bike accident. Can you tell me what happened and what kind of injuries you sustained?
Patient: Yeah, I had a pretty bad crash and ended up with a type II distal diaphyseal tibia fracture and a segmental fibula fracture. They checked my leg and found a 1 cm wound with some grass in it.
Doctor: It looks like they performed a neurovascular assessment and didn't find any deficits, which is good. And they did an initial inspection of your leg to assess the wound. Did they do any treatment at that point?
Patient: Yes, they cleaned the wound with irrigation and gave me IV cefazolin, gentamicin, and penicillin. They also applied a splint to my leg.
Doctor: Good, those initial treatments are important. I see that you underwent intraoperative irrigation and debridement within the first 24 hours, and they placed a suprapatellar IMN. How did you feel after the surgery?
Patient: I was okay at first. They gave me two doses of IV Ancef, and I was discharged with a nonweightbearing status on my injured leg.
Doctor: I understand that you started to develop progressive knee discomfort over time. Can you describe the symptoms and when they began?
Patient: Yeah, after about four weeks, I started to have severe pain in my knee. It got really swollen and red, and I could hardly move it.
Doctor: It appears that at that juncture, an examination identified a large knee effusion, erythema, and minimal tolerance for knee range-of-motion. They also inspected the fracture site and found mild erythema with serosanguinous drainage. They aspirated the knee and found cloudy yellow fluid. The analysis showed a white cell count of over 100,000 with 96% neutrophils, and the cultures grew gram-negative rods. Your care was then transferred to me. 
Patient: Yeah, that's when things started to get really serious.
Doctor: We decided to perform an I&D of the knee, fracture site, and intramedullary canal after removing the hardware. During the procedure, we found discolored fluid in the knee and palpable loculations in the suprapatellar pouch. We also found grass in the knee and at the fracture site. 
Patient: That must be why my knee was so infected.
Doctor: Yes, the grass likely contributed to the infection. We performed a synovectomy to remove the loculated tissue in the knee, and we extended the surgical footprint at the fracture site to allow for debridement of the bone and soft tissue. We removed nonviable skin, which resulted in a 1x3 cm soft-tissue defect directly over the anteromedial tibial fracture site. 
Patient: What is the next step in my treatment?
Doctor: We used a reamed irrigator aspirator (RIA) during the procedure, which will help with recovery. Going forward, we will closely monitor your healing process and address any complications that may arise. It's important that you continue to follow the nonweightbearing status on your injured leg and follow up with us regularly.
Patient: Okay, I understand. I'll make sure to follow your instructions and come in for regular check-ups.
Doctor: Great, that's very important for your recovery. We'll do our best to get you back on your feet as soon as possible.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient reports a history of a dirt bike accident resulting in a type II distal diaphyseal tibia fracture and a segmental fibula fracture. He mentions initial treatment included wound irrigation and administration of IV cefazolin, gentamicin, and penicillin, followed by splint application. Post-surgery, he experienced progressive knee discomfort starting about four weeks after the incident, characterized by severe pain, swelling, redness, and restricted movement.
O: Initial assessments revealed a 1 cm wound with foreign material (grass) and no neurovascular deficits. Postoperative treatment included intraoperative irrigation, debridement, and placement of a suprapatellar intramedullary nail (IMN). Follow-up examinations showed a large knee effusion, erythema, and limited knee range-of-motion. Aspiration of the knee yielded cloudy yellow fluid with a white cell count over 100,000 and 96% neutrophils; cultures grew gram-negative rods. Surgical findings included discolored fluid in the knee, palpable loculations, and grass at the fracture site. A synovectomy and extended debridement were performed, resulting in a 1x3 cm soft-tissue defect over the anteromedial tibial fracture site.
A: The primary diagnosis is postoperative infection of the knee and tibia fracture site, likely exacerbated by foreign material (grass) contamination. Differential diagnoses could include non-infectious inflammatory response; however, the presence of high white cell counts and positive cultures confirm infection. The prognosis depends on effective management of the infection and proper wound healing.
P: The patient underwent removal of hardware, I&D of the knee, fracture site, and intramedullary canal, followed by synovectomy and extensive debridement. He was instructed to maintain nonweightbearing status on the affected leg and adhere to a strict follow-up schedule. Ongoing monitoring of the infection and healing process is essential, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on recovery progress and any arising complications. Regular check-ups are crucial for timely intervention and recovery optimization.

Patient: I feel much better now, thank you.
Doctor: That's good to know. I want to inform you that neither you nor the first patient developed any respiratory complications after the surgery. The postoperative chest X-ray showed no notable findings for the first patient. However, in your case, it showed subsegmental atelectasis on the right middle lobe compared to the preoperative findings. We will monitor this closely and take necessary actions if needed. Doctor: Hi there, I see you're here for a follow-up visit, have you been experiencing any new or concerning symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I've been having a painful, enlarging lump in my left breast for some time now.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Let me perform a clinical examination to better understand the issue. Hmm, I can feel a pulsatile mass with a continuous machinery murmur in the outer upper quadrant of your left breast. We'll need to do a Color Doppler imaging to get a clearer picture of the lump. 
Patient: Okay, sure.
Doctor: Based on the Color Doppler imaging, we found an anechoic lump measuring 45 × 26 × 33 mm, fed by an afferent artery. It shows a yin-yang appearance and a biphasic "to-and-fro" pattern. There's also a fistula situated 3-mm proximal to the anechoic lump, connecting the afferent artery and a concomitant vein. 
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: Based on these findings, you've been diagnosed with breast PA-AVF. Don't worry, we'll take good care of you. We've consulted with a multidisciplinary team and determined that the lesion poses a risk of rupture. It's recommended that the lesion be excised and ligated under local anesthesia as soon as possible.
Patient: I see. How will the procedure be done?
Doctor: We'll make a 3-mm operative incision along the direction of the vascular route under ultrasonography guidance. The incision will be at the 1 o'clock position, 7 cm from the nipple, and it'll be concealed to prevent any cosmetic defect. We'll then ligate the proximal and distal artery and vein of the PA-AVF and excise it.
Patient: Is the surgery complicated?
Doctor: No, the entire operation is quite simple and time-efficient. The mean bleeding volume is only 5 mL, so it's relatively safe.
Patient: That's reassuring. When can we schedule the surgery?
Doctor: We can schedule it as soon as possible. Let's discuss the available dates and make an appointment.
*One month after the surgery*
Doctor: How are you feeling since the surgery? Any complications or concerns?
Patient: I feel much better, and the wound seems to have healed well.
Doctor: That's great to hear! Let's perform an ultrasonography to confirm the disappearance of the breast PA-AVF. Yes, the ultrasonography confirms that the breast PA-AVF has disappeared. The surgery was successful, and you should continue to heal well.
Patient: Thank you so much for your help, Doctor. I appreciate it.
Doctor: You're welcome! If you have any concerns or issues in the future, don't hesitate to contact us. Take care!

A fistula was noted 3-mm proximal to the lump, connecting the afferent artery and a concomitant vein. Post-operative ultrasonography confirmed the disappearance of the breast PA-AVF.
A: The diagnosis is breast pseudoaneurysm-arteriovenous fistula (PA-AVF). The lesion was at risk of rupture, necessitating surgical intervention.
P: The management plan included excision and ligation of the lesion under local anesthesia, guided by ultrasonography. The surgery involved making a 3-mm operative incision at the 1 o'clock position, 7 cm from the nipple, with ligation of the proximal and distal artery and vein of the PA-AVF. dialogue:

Patient: Hi, doctor. My 30-month-old son has been having abdominal bloating and persistent diarrhea after every feeding for the past four months. His stools are foul-smelling and occur more than four times a day.
Doctor: I see. Has this been associated with any failure to gain weight?
Patient: Yes, he hasn't been gaining weight like he should.
Doctor: Has your child had a normal appetite with no history of vomiting or feeding intolerance?
Patient: Yes, he has a normal appetite and hasn't had any problems with vomiting or feeding.
Doctor: Has there been any history of fever, night sweats, rash, cough, or joint pain?
Patient: No, there hasn't been any of those symptoms.
Doctor: Has your child been in contact with anyone who's been sick recently?
Patient: No, he hasn't had any recent sick contact.
Doctor: I understand your child has seen several general practitioners for the same complaint, but no diagnosis was obtained. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Can you tell me about your child's past medical history? Any hospital admissions or surgeries?
Patient: He's had an unremarkable past medical history, with no hospital admissions or surgeries.
Doctor: Does your child take any medications or have any food or drug allergies?
Patient: No, he doesn't take any medications, and he doesn't have any known food or drug allergies.
Doctor: Was your child full term, and what was his birth weight?
Patient: Yes, he was full term, and his birth weight was 3.5 kg.
Doctor: How was the labor and delivery? Were there any complications?
Patient: The labor and delivery went smoothly, with no complications.
Doctor: Is your child up to date with his vaccination schedule?
Patient: Yes, he's up to date with his vaccinations.
Doctor: Have you had any parental concern regarding his development?
Patient: No, he's been reaching his developmental milestones on time, and we haven't had any concerns.
Doctor: What about your child's social history and family history? Any diseases running in the family or consanguineous marriage?
Patient: No, there's no history of diseases running in the family, and we're not related by blood.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Upon examination, your child is awake and alert and does not appear sick. No dysmorphic features are noted. He is below the second standard deviations for weight and height. He appears pale, but there's no scleral icterus. His vital signs are as follows: heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure of 80/52 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 bpm, and temperature of 36.8°C. His abdominal examination reveals a soft and non-tender abdomen with no organomegaly and normal bowel sounds. His neurological examination, including hearing and vision tests, is normal.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. What should we do next?

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having blurred vision for about a month now.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about any medical history or surgeries you've had recently?
Patient: Yes, I had a laparoscopic myomectomy about eight months ago.
Doctor: How did you feel after the procedure?
Patient: Well, two months after the surgery, I started having abdominal pain and hardness over my anterior abdominal wall. So, I went to see my gynecologist.
Doctor: What did they find?
Patient: They did an ultrasound examination and an MRI study which showed fluid collections along the subcutaneous and muscular plane with adjacent subcutaneous edema.
Doctor: Did they perform any additional tests?
Patient: Yes, they did a fine needle aspiration cytology and the tissue sample revealed a necrotizing granulomatous inflammation of likely mycobacterial origin.
Doctor: What treatment were you given for that?
Patient: I was started on an antituberculous regimen consisting of rifampicin (450 mg/day), ethambutol (800 mg/day), and clarithromycin (1000 mg/day) to cover possible atypical mycobacteria.
Doctor: When did you first notice the blurring and haziness in your eyes?
Patient: I started experiencing it five months after starting the regimen.
Doctor: Did you consult an ophthalmologist about this?
Patient: Yes, I did. They said my visual acuities were 6/6 bilaterally, my anterior segments and fundi appeared normal, and my color vision was normal on Ishihara plates.
Doctor: What did they recommend?
Patient: They discontinued my ethambutol as a precautionary measure, but my symptoms persisted, so I sought a second opinion.
Doctor: What were the findings of the second examination?
Patient: My visual acuity was 6/12 in both eyes, and everything else appeared normal, including pupillary reactions. I underwent baseline perimetry which revealed central bitemporal hemianopia that respected the vertical midline, consistent with ethambutol toxicity.
Doctor: I understand. It seems that ethambutol toxicity is the cause of your vision problems. We will discontinue the ethambutol treatment and I advise you to undergo regular follow-up with your primary physician.
Patient: Okay, thank you, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. At your last follow-up, how was your vision?
Patient: A month later, I was visually asymptomatic and my visual acuities were back to 6/6 bilaterally.
Doctor: That's great to hear. Did you have any further field testing?
Patient: No, I declined further field testing.
Doctor: Alright. Please continue to monitor your vision and consult your primary physician if you have any concerns. Take care.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.

Despite discontinuation of ethambutol and normal visual acuity tests, her symptoms persisted, leading to a diagnosis of ethambutol-induced optic neuropathy.
O: Recent examinations revealed visual acuities of 6/12 in both eyes, normal anterior segments, fundi, color vision, and pupillary reactions. Baseline perimetry showed central bitemporal hemianopia. Previous treatments included rifampicin (450 mg/day), ethambutol (800 mg/day), and clarithromycin (1000 mg/day). Ethambutol has been discontinued due to suspected toxicity.

P: Ethambutol has been discontinued to mitigate further optic damage. The patient is advised to undergo regular follow-up with her primary physician to monitor her vision. Further field testing has been declined by the patient, but regular monitoring for any changes in vision is recommended. The patient should report any deterioration in vision immediately.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you have presented with a worsening cough and shortness of breath. Can you tell me more about your past medical history?
Patient: Yeah, I have Parkinson's disease for about two years now, and it's not really responding to treatment. I also had a surgical splenectomy for some unknown reason, and I used to smoke. Oh, and I have hypertension.
Doctor: I see. Have you noticed any significant changes in your health recently?
Patient: Yes, I've lost about 40 pounds in the last two to three months, and I've been having progressive difficulty swallowing.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. When you first came in, we found that you were hypoxemic and tachycardic. We performed a computed tomography angiography (CTA) of your chest to rule out a pulmonary embolism. The results showed a right hilar mass involving the carina and extending into the subcarinal, right hilar, and paratracheal regions. It also showed encasement of your right mainstem bronchus, bronchus intermedius, and pulmonary artery with evidence of superimposed pneumonia.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: Additionally, we found mediastinal lymphadenopathy and findings suspicious for hepatic and retrocaval metastasis. Your complete blood count revealed a white blood cell count of 1.57 K/mcL, hemoglobin of 10.0 g/dL, hematocrit of 30.2%, and a platelet count of 119 K/mcL.
Patient: What does that all mean?
Doctor: These numbers indicate that you have an underlying infection, so we started you on broad-spectrum antibiotics. You were admitted for treatment of pneumonia and further pulmonary evaluation.
Patient: And what about the biopsy?
Doctor: We performed an endobronchial ultrasound with a biopsy of the level 4L, 7, and 11R lymph nodes. The biopsy revealed tumor cells that were positive for S100 and HMB45 and negative for CK7, CK20, P63, TTF1, and napsin-A. This is consistent with a diagnosis of metastatic melanoma.
Patient: Oh no, that's terrible news.
Doctor: I understand this is difficult news to process. Additionally, we evaluated your pancytopenia with a bone marrow biopsy and aspirate. The marrow showed markedly decreased trilineage hematopoiesis, a hypercellularity of 70% with extensive infiltration by B-cell lymphoma positive for CD20, DBA.44, CD25, and Annexin A and negative for CD3, CD10, CD5, and cyclin d-1.
Patient: What does that mean for me?
Doctor: This means that you have a type of cancer called B-cell lymphoma in addition to the metastatic melanoma. We will need to discuss treatment options and develop a plan moving forward.
Patient: I understand. Thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will do our best to support you through this process. Please don't hesitate to ask any questions or reach out for help.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient, a known case of Parkinson's disease and hypertension, presents with a worsening cough, shortness of breath, significant weight loss of 40 pounds over 2-3 months, and progressive difficulty swallowing. The patient has a history of smoking and a surgical splenectomy.

Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the chest revealed a right hilar mass involving the carina, extending into subcarinal, right hilar, and paratracheal regions, with encasement of the right mainstem bronchus, bronchus intermedius, and pulmonary artery, and evidence of superimposed pneumonia. Mediastinal lymphadenopathy and suspicious findings for hepatic and retrocaval metastasis were noted. Lab results showed white blood cell count of 1.57 K/mcL (normal: 4.5-11 K/mcL), hemoglobin 10.0 g/dL (normal: 13.8-17.2 g/dL for men, 12.1-15.1 g/dL for women), hematocrit 30.2% (normal: 41-50% for men, 36-44% for women), and platelet count 119 K/mcL (normal: 150-450 K/mcL). Endobronchial ultrasound with biopsy of lymph nodes showed tumor cells positive for S100 and HMB45, consistent with metastatic melanoma. Bone marrow biopsy indicated B-cell lymphoma with extensive infiltration.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic melanoma with secondary diagnosis of B-cell lymphoma. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of cancer or metastatic diseases. The prognosis is guarded due to the advanced stage of cancer and presence of multiple malignancies.
P: The patient was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics for pneumonia and admitted for further pulmonary evaluation. A multidisciplinary team involving oncology, hematology, and pulmonology will be consulted for comprehensive cancer management. Treatment options including chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or immunotherapy will be discussed with the patient. Supportive care, including nutritional support and pain management, will be provided. Regular follow-ups and monitoring of treatment response and side effects will be scheduled. The patient will be educated about the nature of his illnesses, treatment options, and supportive care measures to ensure understanding and compliance.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, Case 1. How can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been feeling really weak and tired lately. I also have pain in my arms and legs, my face looks kind of blue, and I have a fever.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your medical history? Have you had any surgeries or major health issues in the past?
Patient: Yes, I had a splenectomy after an accident a while back.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. I'm going to start you on an empirical antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone (2 g every 12h) and vancomycin (500 mg every 6h). We'll need to run some tests to find out what's causing your symptoms.
Patient: Okay, thank you, Doctor.
(After the tests and analysis)
Doctor: We've received the results of your tests. It appears that you have secondary sepsis caused by meningitis from Streptococcus pneumoniae.
Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is a serious condition. We'll be transferring you to the intensive care unit (ICU) for close monitoring and treatment. Your clinical status has deteriorated, and you're experiencing severe hemodynamic instability, requiring vasopressor support with norepinephrine 0.4 μg/kg/min. You also have persistent hypotension and a pronounced inflammatory state with C-reactive protein (CRP) at 176.3 mg/l and procalcitonin (PCT) at 485.88 ng/ml.
Patient: Wow, that's a lot to take in.
Doctor: I understand. Additionally, you have metabolic abnormalities with lactate levels at 7.8 mmol/l and severe coagulative disorders. Due to your persistent anuria, we'll be starting continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), in the form of hemodiafiltration (CVVHDF, Prismaflex, M150, Baxter, USA), along with a Cytosorb cartridge. This treatment will begin within 24 hours of your ICU admission and will last for a total of 68 hours.
Patient: Will that help me feel better?
Doctor: Yes, we expect to see an improvement during the first treatment. Your PCT should reduce to 6 ng/ml by the end of the treatments, and your CRP should drop to 136.41 mg/l. Your lactate acidosis should also improve, with lactate levels decreasing to 1.9 mmol/dl.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: Additionally, we should see stabilization in your hemodynamic condition, with a reduction in the need for norepinephrine. After 12 days, we'll stop the CRRT, and you should see a recovery in your diuresis.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything to me, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. The next steps will include monitoring your lactate, PCT, and norepinephrine demand during the Cytosorb treatment. We'll do our best to help you recover as quickly as possible.
Patient: I appreciate all of your help, Doctor.

Metabolic abnormalities include lactate levels at 7.8 mmol/l (normal 0.5-2.2 mmol/l) and severe coagulative disorders. The patient also has persistent anuria.
A: The primary diagnosis is secondary sepsis caused by meningitis from Streptococcus pneumoniae. The patient's post-splenectomy status likely contributes to an increased susceptibility to infections, complicating the clinical picture with severe sepsis and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).
P: The patient has been started on empirical antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone (2 g every 12 hours) and vancomycin (500 mg every 6 hours). Due to severe clinical manifestations, the patient will be transferred to the ICU for close monitoring and treatment, including continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) with hemodiafiltration (CVVHDF, Prismaflex, M150, Baxter, USA) and a Cytosorb cartridge for a total of 68 hours. The patient's response to treatment will be monitored through lactate, PCT, and norepinephrine demand during the Cytosorb treatment. dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I was diagnosed with pseudoxanthoma elasticum and I've been experiencing some issues with my vision.
Doctor: I see. Can you please tell me more about the visual symptoms you've been experiencing?
Patient: Sure, I've been having blurry vision in my left eye and it's been affecting my daily activities.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. I can see from your records that you were diagnosed with bilateral AS and CNV secondary to AS in your left eye. You were treated with 12 intravitreal injections of ranibizumab over 13 months. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I also noticed that despite the intensive treatment with ranibizumab, there wasn't any significant functional or anatomic change. One month after the last administration, your best-corrected visual acuity was 10/10 in your right eye and remained stable at 3/10 in your left eye. Fundoscopy demonstrated the peau d'orange fundus appearance and AS as multiple irregular linear branching subretinal streaks. An elevated gray-yellow subretinal lesion compatible with CNV was observed in your left eye, adjacent to a large fibrotic lesion. Do you remember having a fluorescein angiography test done?
Patient: Yes, I remember having that test.
Doctor: The test clearly showed streaks around the optic disc and leakage of the dye originating from the CNV, while staining of the fibrotic element of the foveal lesion was observed. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) imaging also revealed signs of active CNV in your left eye with intraretinal and subretinal fluid accumulation. At that point, it was agreed to switch your treatment to aflibercept, using the proposed treatment regimen for age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Do you recall signing an informed consent form for this new treatment?
Patient: Yes, I do remember signing the consent form.
Doctor: Great. You received a loading dose consisting of 3 consecutive intravitreal injections of aflibercept (2 mg [50 µL]) monthly, followed by bimonthly aflibercept administration at the same dose. How has your vision been since starting this new treatment?
Patient: Actually, I've noticed some improvement in my left eye.
Doctor: That's good to hear. The 3 loading doses of aflibercept led to an improved best-corrected visual acuity of 6/10 in your left eye. dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having this cough for three months now. I haven't traveled outside Djibouti, and I don't have any medical, surgical, or tuberculosis history.
Doctor: I see. Let's do a chest radiograph and some tests to determine the cause of your cough. We'll also test you for HIV.
(After receiving the test results)
Doctor: Your chest radiograph shows a retractile opacity in the right upper lobe of your lung and a para-aortic opacity with micronodules of the culmen. Your HIV test came back negative, which is good news. We also conducted a direct microscopic examination of your sputum smear after Ziehl-Neelsen staining, and it exhibited acid-fast bacilli. However, your sputum was not cultured.
Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean, doc?
Doctor: Based on these findings, I'm diagnosing you with pulmonary tuberculosis. We will start you on first-line antituberculosis drugs to treat your condition.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
(After three months of treatment)
Patient: Hi, doc. I'm back, but my symptoms haven't improved. My cough is still persistent.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Let's perform another direct examination of your sputum and a GeneXpert® MTB/RIF lab test to check for any changes.
(After receiving the test results)
Doctor: Your sputum examination came back positive, and we detected a rifampicin-resistant M. tuberculosis complex isolate. We'll need to hospitalize you and change your treatment plan.
Patient: Alright, what's the new treatment plan?
Doctor: We'll be treating you with daily doses of kanamycin (1 g), moxifloxacin (400 mg), prothionamide (250 mg), clofazimine (100 mg), isoniazid (300 mg), ethionamide (250 mg), and pyrazinamide (400 mg). The doses will be adjusted according to your weight.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
(After a few months of treatment)
Doctor: Your recent sputum culture came back positive, yielding strain 5175, which was identified as an M. tuberculosis complex isolate. However, your symptoms seem to have improved, which is a good sign.
Patient: That's great to hear! Thank you, doc.
Doctor: You're welcome. Let's continue monitoring your progress and adjust your treatment plan as needed. Remember to follow up with us regularly.

The patient is advised to maintain regular appointments and adhere strictly to the prescribed treatment regimen to manage and potentially overcome the infection.

Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me your past medical history?
Patient: Yeah, I have hypertension, diabetes mellitus type 2, ulcerative colitis, coronary artery disease, diastolic congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of 60%, acute pancreatitis, and I had a cholecystectomy in the 1990s.
Doctor: I see. What brings you here today?
Patient: I've been having severe epigastric pain for a day now. It's constant, like 10 out of 10 in severity, and it's radiating to my back. I also have severe nausea, nonbloody nonbilious vomiting, and anorexia.
Doctor: When did these symptoms start?
Patient: They began three days after I started taking metronidazole for C. difficile colitis, which I developed after being treated with antibiotics for cellulitis.
Doctor: Do you have any history of alcohol use, hypertriglyceridemia, recent flu-like illness, travel to parasite endemic areas, direct trauma, lupus, vasculitis, or other autoimmune diseases?
Patient: No, I don't have any of those.
Doctor: What about a family history of pancreatitis or a recent history of endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography?
Patient: No, none of those either.
Doctor: Do you smoke?
Patient: Yes, I have a 20 pack-year smoking history.
Doctor: Can you please tell me your current medications?
Patient: I take albuterol, alprazolam, atorvastatin, clonidine, fluticasone-salmeterol, losartan, loratadine, montelukast, and omeprazole.
Doctor: Thank you. At presentation, your vital signs were stable. During the physical exam, we found a distended abdomen with severe epigastric tenderness and diminished bowel sounds, but no guarding or rebound tenderness. No other abnormal findings were noted.
Doctor: Your lab results on admission showed a white blood cell count of 16,000/μL with neutrophilic predominance and no eosinophilia. Lipase was >396 U/L, but amylase was not measured. Liver function tests were mildly elevated with total bilirubin 0.7 mg/dL, aspartate aminotransferase 59 U/L, and alkaline phosphatase 135 IU/L. Calcium level was 8.6 mg/dL, and triglycerides level was 69 mg/dL.
Patient: What does all that mean?
Doctor: These findings suggest that your severe epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting are likely related to your acute pancreatitis. The elevated lipase and liver function tests support this diagnosis.
Patient: What should I do now?
Doctor: We will closely monitor your condition and provide appropriate treatment for your acute pancreatitis. It's important to follow up with your primary care physician and discuss any changes in your medications, as well as addressing your smoking history. Ensure you keep track of your symptoms and report any worsening or new issues.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you have been diagnosed with kappa light chain multiple myeloma and ESRD. We have treated you with five cycles of CyBorD followed by high-dose cyclophosphamide mobilization and autologous HSCT with melphalan 140 mg/m2 therapy. How are you feeling now?
Patient: I've been feeling quite weak, and I recently had a fever.
Doctor: I see. It appears that you developed a neutropenic fever with Streptococcus sanguinis bacteremia. We have been treating you with vancomycin, cefazolin, and metronidazole for that infection. Have you had any history of liver disease?
Patient: No, I've never had any liver problems before.
Doctor: Your total serum bilirubin level was 3.4 mg/dl at the time of transplantation, and it peaked on treatment day 24 at 22 mg/dl. We performed imaging and discovered ascites, which is fluid in your abdominal cavity. We also conducted a liver biopsy on treatment day 16, which was consistent with SOS (sinusoidal obstruction syndrome).
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What are the next steps in my treatment?
Doctor: We have started treating you with ursodiol, a medication that helps protect the liver. Unfortunately, your condition has worsened, and we were hoping to get defibrotide for you under compassionate use. 
Patient: So, when can I start the defibrotide treatment?
Doctor: I'm sorry to inform you that we were unable to secure the defibrotide in time. Your loved one passed away on treatment day 25. Our deepest condolences to you and your family.
Family Member: Thank you, Doctor. We appreciate all the efforts you and your team made to help him.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient, diagnosed with kappa light chain multiple myeloma and end-stage renal disease (ESRD), reported feeling weak and having a recent fever. The patient denied any history of liver disease.
O: The patient underwent five cycles of CyBorD followed by high-dose cyclophosphamide mobilization and autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) with melphalan at a dose of 140 mg/m2. Developed neutropenic fever with Streptococcus sanguinis bacteremia, treated with vancomycin, cefazolin, and metronidazole. Total serum bilirubin was elevated at 3.4 mg/dl at transplantation, peaking at 22 mg/dl on treatment day 24. Imaging revealed ascites, and liver biopsy on treatment day 16 confirmed sinusoidal obstruction syndrome (SOS). The patient was started on ursodiol for liver protection. Efforts to obtain defibrotide under compassionate use were unsuccessful.
A: The primary diagnosis is kappa light chain multiple myeloma with complications including ESRD, neutropenic fever with bacteremia, and SOS post-HSCT. The prognosis was poor, leading to the patient's demise on treatment day 25.
P: Treatment included administration of CyBorD, high-dose cyclophosphamide, and autologous HSCT with melphalan. Management of complications involved antibiotics for bacteremia and ursodiol for SOS. Attempts were made to secure defibrotide for SOS under compassionate use, which were not successful. Palliative care and support were provided until the patient's passing.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I'm a 73-year-old female smoker. I came to the emergency department because I've been experiencing right-sided inguinal pain and difficulties in passing urine for the past 2 days.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any medical issues in the past?
Patient: Yes, I had pancreatic cancer and underwent pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy in 2005.
Doctor: Okay. Have you had any fever recently?
Patient: No, I haven't had any fever.
Doctor: Upon examination, I found a 3-cm palpable aching mass in your right inguinal/femoral region. There's no apparent erythema or other signs of infection in the cutaneous region overlying the mass. Your CRP and WBC are normal, at 1.8 mg/L and 4.4 × 109/L, respectively. We performed a CT scan and it revealed a suspected femoral hernia with adjacent inflammation and a tubular structure, presumed to be the vermiform appendix, in the hernia-sack. There were no radiological signs of small bowel obstruction.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. What's the next step?
Doctor: We're going to administer preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis, including metronidazole and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. You'll then undergo open preperitoneal surgery to reposition the hernia.
Patient: And what will happen during the surgery?
Doctor: During the surgery, the peritoneum will be opened and we'll find the inflamed, but not perforated, appendix in the hernia. There will be no signs of bowel obstruction. After the appendectomy, we'll place a partially absorbable lightweight mesh (Ultrapro®) and adhere it with fibrin glue to cover the inguinal and femoral region.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: Postoperative clinical examination of the appendix will reveal a transmural inflammation in the distal third of the appendix. No macroscopic tumor will be present. You'll be discharged the day after surgery.
Patient: That's good to hear. But what if something goes wrong after I'm discharged?
Doctor: You'll actually be readmitted 4 days after surgery due to constipation. A surgical-site seroma will develop, but it will be treated conservatively. All of your symptoms will resolve 4 weeks after surgery.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll monitor your progress and make sure you're on the right track to recovery. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out to us.

S: The patient is a 73-year-old female smoker presenting with right-sided inguinal pain and difficulties in passing urine for the past 2 days. She has a history of pancreatic cancer treated with pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy in 2005. She denies having a fever.
O: Physical examination revealed a 3-cm palpable, aching mass in the right inguinal/femoral region without erythema or signs of infection. Laboratory tests showed normal C-reactive protein (CRP) at 1.8 mg/L and white blood cell count (WBC) at 4.4 × 10^9/L. CT scan indicated a suspected femoral hernia with adjacent inflammation and a tubular structure presumed to be the vermiform appendix in the hernia sac, without signs of small bowel obstruction.
A: The primary diagnosis is right femoral hernia with involvement of the appendix, known as Amyand's hernia. Differential diagnosis could include simple femoral hernia without appendiceal involvement. The prognosis is generally good with appropriate surgical intervention.
P: The management plan includes preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis with metronidazole and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, followed by open preperitoneal surgery to reposition the hernia and perform an appendectomy. A partially absorbable lightweight mesh (Ultrapro®) will be used for reinforcement. Postoperative care will involve monitoring for complications such as constipation and surgical-site seroma, which are expected to resolve with conservative treatment. The patient will be educated on signs of complications and encouraged to maintain communication with healthcare providers.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing purpura, central obesity, facial plethora, and hypertension. I think I might have Cushing's syndrome.
Doctor: Based on your presentation, it is possible that you have Cushing's syndrome. We'll need to run some tests to confirm this.
Patient: Okay, what kind of tests?
Doctor: We'll check for ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome, which could be due to a pituitary tumor. In your case, your symptoms and test results confirmed ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome, likely of pituitary etiology. 
Patient: Oh wow, so what's the next step?
Doctor: The next step was a transsphenoidal surgery to remove the tumor. During your first surgery, the tumor was visualized but no sample was obtained for pathological analysis.
Patient: Yeah, I remember that. So what happened after that?
Doctor: With persistent postoperative hypercortisolism, a repeat transsphenoidal surgery was completed two months later. This time, a corticotroph adenoma was confirmed on pathology.
Patient: But I still felt off after the second surgery...
Doctor: Yes, you remained hypercortisolemic after the second surgery. One year later, we started you on cabergoline 1 mg twice weekly for persistent and moderately elevated 24-hour UFC levels.
Patient: Oh, I see. But I had to stop taking the medication for a while...
Doctor: At age 54, during a period of medication nonadherence, your 24-hour UFC increased to twice normal. Two months later, you presented to the hospital with a three-day history of worsening left lower quadrant abdominal pain.
Patient: Yeah, the pain was really bad.
Doctor: A CT scan of your abdomen showed a large collection of stool and gas centrally in the mesentery, on the background of multiple diverticulae. Surgery was needed to address this issue.
Patient: What did the surgery find?
Doctor: During the surgery, a 1.5 × 3 cm perforation of the sigmoid colon was found, with features more consistent with a perforated stercoral ulcer rather than a diverticular perforation. A distal sigmoidectomy with the creation of an end colostomy was performed.
Patient: I'm glad that was taken care of. How am I doing now?
Doctor: You're doing well and have remained eucortisolemic on cabergoline 1 mg twice weekly. It's important to continue taking your medication as prescribed and follow up with regular check-ups.
Patient: Thank you, doctor! I'll make sure to adhere to my medication and follow-up appointments.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient reports experiencing purpura, central obesity, facial plethora, and hypertension. He suspects he might have Cushing's syndrome. He recalls undergoing two transsphenoidal surgeries for a pituitary tumor, with the second surgery confirming a corticotroph adenoma. Despite surgeries, he remained hypercortisolemic and was started on cabergoline 1 mg twice weekly. He admits to a period of medication nonadherence at age 54, which was followed by severe left lower quadrant abdominal pain.
O: The patient's initial symptoms and subsequent test results confirmed ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome of pituitary etiology. Postoperative persistence of hypercortisolism was noted. A CT scan of the abdomen revealed a large collection of stool and gas in the mesentery with multiple diverticulae. Surgery identified a 1.5 × 3 cm perforation of the sigmoid colon, managed by distal sigmoidectomy and creation of an end colostomy. Current medication includes cabergoline 1 mg twice weekly, with recent lab tests indicating eucortisolemia.
A: The primary diagnosis is Cushing's syndrome due to a pituitary corticotroph adenoma, complicated by postoperative persistent hypercortisolism and a significant episode of sigmoid colon perforation secondary to stercoral ulcer. Differential diagnosis initially included other causes of Cushing's syndrome.
P: Continue cabergoline 1 mg twice weekly to manage Cushing's syndrome. Emphasize the importance of medication adherence to prevent recurrence of hypercortisolism and associated complications. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor cortisol levels and overall health status. Educate the patient on the signs of cortisol imbalance and when to seek immediate medical attention. A referral to a gastroenterologist is recommended for ongoing management of colon health post-surgery.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, welcome to the Department of Conservative Dentistry and Endodontics at SGT Dental College. How can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing severe pain in my right lower back tooth region for the last three days. The pain comes and goes, but it gets worse when I eat or drink something hot.
Doctor: I see. Let's do a clinical evaluation to find out what's causing the pain. 
(After evaluation)
Doctor: It appears that you have secondary caries associated with your restored right mandibular first molar. We'll need to take a diagnostic radiograph to get a better view.
(After radiograph)
Doctor: The radiograph shows restoration close to the pulp and the presence of an additional root. We took another radiograph at 30-degree mesial and distal angulation to confirm this. We'll need to perform an access cavity preparation under local anesthesia using an endo access bur from Dentsply, Switzerland.
Patient: Okay, what's the next step after that?
Doctor: We'll locate the first distal canal towards the buccal side, which indicates the presence of one additional canal on the lingual side. The shape of the access cavity will be modified from triangular to trapezoidal to locate the fourth canal. A DG-16 endodontic explorer will be used to locate the root canal orifices, and a 15 # K-file from Mani, Japan will be used to establish patency of the canals.
Patient: Got it. How do you determine the working length?
Doctor: We'll determine the working length using an apex locator, Root ZX from J. Morita, and reconfirm it radiographically. Biomechanical preparation will be done with a rotary ProTaper Next file system from Dentsply, Switzerland.
Patient: What will you use for irrigation during the procedure?
Doctor: During instrumentation, we'll use 1.3% sodium hypochlorite as an irrigant and 17% EDTA as the final flush.
Patient: And how will you perform the obturation?
Doctor: We'll perform the obturation with gutta-percha points using a cold lateral condensation technique. After that, we'll restore the access cavity with composite resin from Tetric-N-Ceram, Ivoclar Vivadent, and take a post-obturation radiograph.
Patient: So, what can I expect after the treatment?
Doctor: At your 6-month follow-up, you should be asymptomatic and free of pain. Radiographic evaluation should show no evidence of pathology.
Patient: That's great to hear. Thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or concerns, feel free to ask. We're here to help you.
ground_truth_soap:

O: Clinical evaluation revealed secondary caries associated with a previously restored right mandibular first molar. Diagnostic radiographs confirmed the restoration proximity to the pulp and identified an additional root. Radiographs taken at different angulations helped in planning the access cavity preparation. The patient's vital signs and other systemic parameters were not mentioned.
A: The primary diagnosis is secondary caries with possible pulp involvement in the right mandibular first molar, necessitating endodontic treatment. Differential diagnoses could include pulpitis or periapical abscess, but these would require further confirmation through clinical and radiographic evaluation.
P: The treatment plan includes performing an access cavity preparation under local anesthesia, using specific endodontic tools and techniques to locate and treat all root canals. Irrigation will be done using 1.3% sodium hypochlorite and 17% EDTA. Obturation will be performed using gutta-percha with a cold lateral condensation technique, followed by restoration of the cavity with composite resin. A post-obturation radiograph will be taken to confirm the adequacy of the treatment. The patient will be scheduled for a 6-month follow-up to monitor the treatment outcome and ensure the absence of symptoms or pathology.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I see you've presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain that's been going on for one night. This pain has been causing you difficulty with sleeping and walking, is that correct?
Patient: Yeah, that's right. It's been really hard to get any rest or move around.
Doctor: Have you experienced any loss of appetite, vomiting, or fever along with this pain?
Patient: No, I haven't lost my appetite or been vomiting, but I did have a fever earlier.
Doctor: I noticed that you had an appendectomy 19 months ago due to similar symptoms and were diagnosed with appendicitis. Were there any complications during or after that surgery?
Patient: No, there weren't any problems during or after the surgery.
Doctor: Have you had a bowel movement in the last few days?
Patient: Hmm, now that you mention it, I haven't had one for several days.
Doctor: When you first arrived, we performed a physical examination and found signs of fever and localized peritonitis. Your lab results showed leukocytosis of 13,300 per cubic millimeter, which is above the reference range of 4,500-13,000, and neutrophilia of 9,870 per cubic millimeter, also above the reference range of 1,700-7,500. Your C-reactive peptide was elevated at 1.4 milligrams per deciliter, with the normal range being below 0.5. After giving you antipyretics, your fever has reduced, but you're still experiencing severe abdominal pain.
Patient: That's correct, the pain is still really bad.
Doctor: We also did a point-of-care ultrasound, which showed a normal gallbladder and no dilation of the common bile duct. However, it did demonstrate an aperistaltic mass in your right lower quadrant.
Patient: Oh, what does that mean?
Doctor: It means there's an abnormal mass in that area. After consulting with the pediatric surgery team, we performed a contrast-enhanced computed tomography of your abdomen and pelvis. This showed surgical changes from your previous appendectomy with staple lines at the blind end of the appendiceal stump. There was also a high-density appendicolith obstructing the base of the stump, surrounded by mesenteric fat stranding. Thickening of the appendiceal wall and peritoneal reflection of the right lower quadrant were found, which are consistent with acute appendicitis. There was no pneumoperitoneum.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: We've admitted you to the hospital and you'll be undergoing laparoscopic surgery tomorrow. Surgical exploration will be done to address the inflamed appendiceal stump and the pus found in your right paracolic gutter.
Patient: And will that fix the issue?
Doctor: Yes, the surgery should help resolve the inflammation and pain. However, the appendiceal wall is very friable, so the surgeon will need to be cautious during the procedure. We'll continue to monitor your condition and provide appropriate care after the surgery.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient, a 19-month post-appendectomy individual, presented with severe abdominal pain persisting for one night, causing difficulty in sleeping and walking. The patient reported a fever but no loss of appetite or vomiting. The patient also noted an absence of bowel movements for several days.
O: Physical examination revealed fever and localized peritonitis. Laboratory tests showed leukocytosis (13,300 per cubic millimeter) and neutrophilia (9,870 per cubic millimeter), both above normal ranges. C-reactive peptide was elevated at 1.4 mg/dL. Point-of-care ultrasound showed a normal gallbladder and no common bile duct dilation but revealed an aperistaltic mass in the right lower quadrant. Contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis indicated surgical changes from a previous appendectomy, an obstructing high-density appendicolith at the appendiceal stump, surrounded by mesenteric fat stranding, and thickening of the appendiceal wall consistent with acute appendicitis. No pneumoperitoneum was observed.
A: The primary diagnosis is stump appendicitis with an obstructing appendicolith and associated inflammation. Differential diagnosis could include other causes of right lower quadrant pain, but imaging and history strongly support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis is good with appropriate surgical intervention, though caution is advised due to the friability of the appendiceal wall.
P: The patient has been admitted for urgent laparoscopic surgery to remove the inflamed appendiceal stump and address the pus in the right paracolic gutter. Post-operative care will include monitoring for complications and managing pain. Education regarding post-surgical care and signs of potential complications will be provided to ensure compliance and prompt response to any issues. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and ensure complete resolution of the condition.

Doctor: Good morning. I see you have a past medical history of hypertension. Can you tell me about the symptoms you've been experiencing lately?
Patient: Well, about a week after I had a respiratory viral infection, I started to develop some progressive cerebellar ataxia. I've been having trouble speaking clearly and my walking has become unsteady.
Doctor: I see. How long have your symptoms worsened?
Patient: They got worse for about 2 weeks and then remained stable.
Doctor: When were you admitted to our service?
Patient: I was admitted a year after my symptoms started.
Doctor: It seems that you were previously diagnosed with parainfectious cerebellar ataxia. Have you experienced any other symptoms recently?
Patient: Yes, I've had daily nausea and vomiting for the past 6 months, I lost 66 pounds, and I've been feeling tingling in my hands and feet.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. Now, let's discuss the results of your neurological examination. It revealed severe dysarthria, bilateral horizontal nystagmus, pronounced ataxia, and bilateral dysdiadochokinesia. You're unable to stand or walk unattended, but there's no muscle weakness. We also observed generalized hypotonia, and your deep tendon reflexes were normal in the upper limbs and absent in the lower limbs.
Patient: Hmm, I see. What about the other tests?
Doctor: There was distal pinprick hypoesthesia in both your upper and lower limbs, with reduced proprioception and vibration sense in the lower limbs. Your cognition is preserved, and you reported no mood complaints. You also denied having any bowel or bladder dysfunction. Your blood exams were unremarkable.
Patient: What did the electromyography reveal?
Doctor: The electromyography showed severe axonal sensitive polyneuropathy in all four limbs, with mild motor involvement.
Patient: And what treatment have I been given?
Doctor: You were prescribed high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1 g qd for 3 days based on the hypothesis of an auto-immune condition. However, there was no clinical improvement. We also performed serological screening, including protein electrophoresis, anti-tissue transglutaminase IgG and IgA, anti-gliadin IgA, IgG, IgM, and anti-GAD, but the results were non-reactive.
Patient: Did you test for any other conditions?
Doctor: Yes, we tested for paraneoplastic antibodies, including anti-HU, anti-YO, anti-RI, anti-amphiphysin, anti-CV2, anti-MA2, anti-MGT30, AGNA, and anti-recoverin. The results were negative.
Patient: What about the lumbar puncture?
Doctor: The lumbar puncture was performed 1 year after your symptoms started, and the spinal fluid analysis showed 4 cells and protein. We will continue to monitor your condition and explore other possible causes of your symptoms. Please continue to follow up with us and let us know if there are any changes in your symptoms or if you have any concerns.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, reports progressive cerebellar ataxia starting a week after a respiratory viral infection, characterized by severe dysarthria, unsteady gait, and inability to walk or stand unattended. Symptoms worsened over two weeks and then stabilized. Additional symptoms include daily nausea, vomiting for six months, significant weight loss (66 pounds), and tingling in hands and feet. No recent bowel or bladder dysfunction or mood changes reported.
O: Neurological examination revealed severe dysarthria, bilateral horizontal nystagmus, pronounced ataxia, bilateral dysdiadochokinesia, generalized hypotonia, and absent deep tendon reflexes in lower limbs. Sensory examination showed distal pinprick hypoesthesia, reduced proprioception, and vibration sense in lower limbs. Electromyography indicated severe axonal sensitive polyneuropathy with mild motor involvement. Blood tests were unremarkable. Serological screening for autoimmune and paraneoplastic conditions was negative. Lumbar puncture showed 4 cells and protein in spinal fluid.
A: The primary diagnosis is parainfectious cerebellar ataxia, likely secondary to a viral infection, with differential diagnoses including autoimmune or paraneoplastic syndromes, both currently unsupported by serological and clinical findings. The presence of severe axonal polyneuropathy suggests a complex, possibly multi-factorial neurological disorder.
P: Continue high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone treatment and monitor for any clinical improvement. Further diagnostic workup may include repeated lumbar puncture, MRI of the brain and spinal cord, and possibly a biopsy if indicated by clinical progression. Regular follow-ups to assess symptom progression and response to treatment are essential. Patient education regarding the nature of the illness, expected outcomes, and importance of reporting new symptoms or changes in condition is crucial. Referral to a neurologist specializing in autoimmune and paraneoplastic neurological disorders is recommended for comprehensive management and second opinion.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I understand you have a past medical history of HIV with a CD4 count of 32/mm3, and you've presented to the emergency department today with a chief complaint of left-sided weakness and altered mental status. Can you tell me more about these symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, doc. I've been feeling really weak on my left side, and I've been having trouble thinking clearly.
Doctor: I see. Have you been falling asleep intermittently or been a poor historian during any conversations recently?
Patient: Yeah, I've been dozing off quite a bit and having trouble remembering things.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing. I also learned from your family that you were diagnosed with HIV more than 5 years ago and have been noncompliant with treatments. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, I haven't been taking my medications regularly.
Doctor: During the physical examination, we noted that your vital signs are mostly stable, but you have an elevated blood pressure of 150/92 mm Hg. Also, there's an 8-cm fixed, subcutaneous mass on your left frontoparietal skull. The rest of the dermatologic examination revealed intact skin without erythema or ulceration. 
Patient: Oh, I didn't realize I had a mass on my skull.
Doctor: Yes, it's something we need to investigate further. We also did some laboratory tests and found mild leukocytosis (10.7 × 109/L) and neutrophilia (6.4 × 109/L). We performed a computed tomography (CT) scan of your head without contrast, which showed no intracranial hemorrhage. However, we found multiple masses, including a 2.8-cm right superior frontal intra-axial hyperdense mass with an adjacent mixed density 2.7-cm right frontal mass, a 1.6-cm right frontal nodule, a 7-mm right frontal hypodense nodule, and a 1.3-cm left frontal nodule. These lesions were associated with marked surrounding infiltrative versus vasogenic edema, which are suspicious for malignancy.
Patient: That sounds serious, doc.
Doctor: Yes, it is concerning. In addition, we found a left frontal infiltrative osseous mass with overlying soft tissue swelling, which is compatible with malignancy. We did subsequent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of your brain and found a 2.5-cm destructive bone lesion in your left frontal skull with a large soft tissue mass in the left frontal scalp and multiple enhancing masses in both cerebral hemispheres measuring up to 2.8 cm in diameter with surrounding edema. These findings are consistent with metastatic disease to the brain and skull.
Patient: Oh no, what does that mean for me?
Doctor: It means that there is a possibility of cancer that has spread to your brain and skull. We also performed a chest X-ray, which showed a 4.3-cm left hilar mass, and a CT scan of your chest, abdomen, and pelvis, revealing a 6.2 × 3.8 cm lobulated mass. These findings further indicate the possibility of cancer.
Patient: What should I do now, doc?
Doctor: We need to perform further tests to confirm the diagnosis and determine the best course of treatment for you. We will also discuss your case with a team of specialists to ensure the best possible care. It's important to follow up with your medical appointments and consider being more compliant with your HIV treatments.
Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor. I'll follow your advice and try to be more compliant with my treatments.
ground_truth_soap:

O: Vital signs show elevated blood pressure at 150/92 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals an 8-cm fixed subcutaneous mass on the left frontoparietal skull. Laboratory tests indicate mild leukocytosis (10.7 × 109/L) and neutrophilia (6.4 × 109/L). CT and MRI scans of the head reveal multiple brain masses and a destructive bone lesion in the left frontal skull, suggestive of metastatic disease. Chest X-ray and CT scans show a 4.3-cm left hilar mass and a 6.2 × 3.8 cm lobulated mass in the chest, respectively.
A: Primary assessment suggests metastatic cancer involving the brain, skull, and possibly the chest, in the context of advanced HIV infection and immunosuppression. Differential diagnoses could include primary brain tumors and opportunistic infections due to low CD4 count.
P: Plan to perform additional diagnostic tests to confirm the nature of the masses and extent of spread. Referral to oncology for evaluation of potential cancer treatment and to infectious disease for management of HIV. Emphasize the importance of medication compliance and schedule regular follow-up appointments. Discuss the prognosis and treatment options with a multidisciplinary team to ensure comprehensive care.
