dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that you have a history of acute inflammatory demyelinating process and have recently been experiencing a mass in your left hand. Can you tell me more about when you first noticed it?
Patient: Yeah, about 3 months ago, I started feeling this mass on my left wrist and the hypothenar area of my hand. It's been getting more and more uncomfortable.
Doctor: I see. You were admitted to the hospital with generalized weakness, ataxia, and multiple sensory deficits, including a complete lack of sensation in your left small finger and the ulnar side of your hand. Can you tell me more about these symptoms?
Patient: Sure, I've been feeling really weak and unsteady, and I've lost all feeling in my left pinky and the side of my hand. It's been really difficult to do things with my left hand.
Doctor: We initially thought that the sensory deficits were related to your demyelinating disorder, but upon examination, we believe that the ulnar deficit is related to the mass in your hand. The mass is soft, nontender, and doesn't limit your range of motion. Your grip strength seems decreased compared to your other hand, though we haven't measured it objectively yet. Have you experienced any trauma, previous surgeries, or other masses in the past?
Patient: No, I haven't had any trauma or surgeries, and I've never had any other masses before.
Doctor: We've also done radiographs of your left upper extremity, which appeared normal. Our initial diagnosis is that the mass could be a lipoma. We conducted a magnetic resonance angiography of your left hand to get a better understanding of the mass, but its etiology is still unclear (Fig. ).
Patient: Hmm, so what's the next step, then?
Doctor: We performed an operative excision under general anesthesia to remove the mass. We made a longitudinally oriented ulnar-sided skin incision, dissected the palmar fascia, and released Guyon's canal. The mass was found to be arising from beneath the hypothenar musculature, and it appeared tan-white, rubbery, and lobulated (Fig. ).
Patient: What did the pathology report say?
Doctor: The pathology report confirmed that the mass is a benign myxoma (Fig. ). There were no postoperative complications, which is a good sign.
Patient: That's a relief. How am I recovering from the surgery?
Doctor: At 5 weeks postoperatively, you reported marked improvement in your numbness and weakness. We found that you have intact sensation in the ulnar nerve distribution distal to the site of the excised mass, and your grip strength has improved.
Patient: That's great to hear! What do I need to do now?
Doctor: We would like you to return in several months for a repeat sensorimotor assessment. However, I understand that you were subsequently lost to follow-up. It's important that we continue to monitor your progress and ensure that there are no further issues.
Patient: Okay, I'll make sure to schedule an appointment for the assessment. Thanks for helping me through this process.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient, with a history of acute inflammatory demyelinating process, reported noticing a mass on the left wrist and hypothenar area about 3 months ago, which has been progressively causing discomfort. The patient also experiences generalized weakness, ataxia, and sensory deficits including a complete lack of sensation in the left small finger and the ulnar side of the hand, making it difficult to use the left hand.
O: Physical examination revealed a soft, nontender mass in the left hand that does not limit range of motion but is associated with decreased grip strength. Radiographs of the left upper extremity were normal. Magnetic resonance angiography was performed but did not clarify the etiology of the mass. Operative excision under general anesthesia was conducted, and the pathology report confirmed the mass as a benign myxoma. dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you're an 8-year-old female patient who was diagnosed with congenital heart disease during infancy, but had unknown follow-up and treatment. What brings you here today?
Patient: I've been feeling really tired and having trouble breathing when I'm playing with my friends. It started about a month ago.
Doctor: I see. When you were admitted to the hospital, we did a physical examination and found a systolic murmur in your left para-sternum. An echocardiography was also performed, revealing a peri-membranous VSD with a diameter of 12 mm, left to right shunting, and a pressure gradient of 20 mmHg. Additionally, we found a PDA with a diameter of 4 mm. 
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. What did you do to treat it?
Doctor: First, we performed a trans-catheter PDA closure. Then, 3 weeks later, we did a TES for VSD repair without robotic assistance. During the procedure, you were placed in a supine position with your arms along your body, under general anesthesia with a single-lumen endotracheal tube.
Patient: What else did you do during the surgery?
Doctor: We used a no.6 Knitted Dacron graft to connect your right common FA with an end-to-side anastomosis. The other side of the graft was connected to the arterial line of the cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) machine. We also inserted SVC and IVC cannulae via your internal jugular vein (IJV) and femoral vein, respectively, using the Seldinger technique.
Patient: And then what happened?
Doctor: When we started the CPB, your arterial pressure gradually increased to 260 mmHg. So, we switched to bilateral FA cannulation by inserting an additional 10Fr FA cannula directly into your left common FA. After that, your arterial pressure declined and stabilized at 180-200 mmHg.
Patient: How did you perform the surgery?
Doctor: We placed four soft trocars in the right side of your chest to assist with the procedure.
Patient: I see. Thank you for explaining everything to me, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. It's important that you understand your condition and the treatment you received. Please make sure to attend your follow-up appointments so we can monitor your progress and ensure a successful recovery.

O: Physical examination revealed a systolic murmur in the left para-sternum. Echocardiography showed a peri-membranous ventricular septal defect (VSD) with a diameter of 12 mm, left to right shunting, and a pressure gradient of 20 mmHg, and a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with a diameter of 4 mm. Trans-catheter PDA closure and transcatheter endocardial septal (TES) VSD repair were performed. During surgery, arterial pressure issues were managed by adjusting cannulation strategies, and a no.6 Knitted Dacron graft was used for vascular connection.
A: The primary diagnosis is a peri-membranous VSD and PDA. The patient underwent successful PDA closure and VSD repair. The immediate post-operative period was complicated by high arterial pressures, which were managed by surgical adjustments.
P: The patient is advised to attend regular follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and ensure the success of the surgical interventions. Education regarding the importance of follow-up care is emphasized to ensure compliance and to monitor for potential complications or the need for further interventions.

Doctor: Hi, I understand that you're a 64-year-old woman with cirrhosis secondary to Hepatitis C. You were recently transplanted to treat drug-induced fulminant hepatitis failure. Can you tell me about your symptoms and how you're feeling?
Patient: Yes, after the transplant, I was given a standard post-op immunosuppressive protocol with corticosteroids, tacrolimus, and mycophenolate mofetil. I also received caspofungin for targeted prophylaxis against IA.
Doctor: It seems that you had a difficult early post-operative period with hemorrhagic episodes and peri-hepatic hematoma, which required several re-interventions. Were you able to maintain the antifungal prophylactic treatment during this time?
Patient: Yes, I continued the treatment even during those interventions.
Doctor: Unfortunately, from post-operative day 31, you developed several septic shocks caused by Enterococcus faecium, Escherichia coli, and Candida glabrata. Were you treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics at that time?
Patient: Yes, they gave me antibiotics and also reintroduced caspofungin.
Doctor: I see that on post-operative day 63, you had a fever resistant to antibiotics. Did you have any other symptoms or discomfort?
Patient: Well, I was feeling very weak, and my chest was hurting a bit.
Doctor: Your chest CT-scan showed right-sided pleural effusion with passive atelectasis and alveolar opacity. They performed a broncho-alveolar lavage (BAL) on you, and the direct examination displayed Aspergillus-like branched hyphae. Were you aware of these findings?
Patient: Yes, the doctor mentioned something about that.
Doctor: At the same time, your galactomannan (GM) antigen index and (1–3)-β-D-glucan (BDG) in serum, which were previously negative, became positive. Your GM antigen index was > 6 (threshold index: 0.5), and your BDG was 234 pg/mL (threshold value: 80 pg/mL). Did they inform you about these results?
Patient: Yes, they said that my antigen levels were higher than normal.
Doctor: They also found that the Aspergillus real-time PCR was positive in your serum with a Cq value of 35. Based on the data from the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer/Mycoses Study Group, you were classified as having probable invasive aspergillosis. This may be contributing to your fever and chest pain. We will need to adjust your treatment to address this infection.
Patient: Oh, I see. What should I do now?
Doctor: We will work closely with your transplant team to manage the infection and monitor your progress. It's important to follow the treatment plan and keep us informed of any changes in your symptoms. We'll do our best to help you recover and maintain your health.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and guidance.
ground_truth_soap:

Despite this, she experienced hemorrhagic episodes, peri-hepatic hematoma, and multiple septic shocks attributed to Enterococcus faecium, Escherichia coli, and Candida glabrata, necessitating broad-spectrum antibiotics and reintroduction of caspofungin.
O: Post-operative complications included hemorrhagic episodes and peri-hepatic hematoma requiring re-interventions. On post-operative day 63, a CT scan revealed right-sided pleural effusion, passive atelectasis, and alveolar opacity. Broncho-alveolar lavage showed Aspergillus-like branched hyphae. Laboratory tests showed elevated galactomannan antigen index > 6 (threshold index: 0.5) and (1–3)-β-D-glucan at 234 pg/mL (threshold value: 80 pg/mL). Aspergillus real-time PCR in serum was positive with a Cq value of 35, confirming probable invasive aspergillosis.
A: The primary diagnosis is probable invasive aspergillosis post liver transplantation, complicating the patient's recovery. This diagnosis is supported by imaging, laboratory findings, and clinical symptoms of fever and chest pain. Differential diagnoses could include other opportunistic infections due to immunosuppressive therapy.
P: The management plan will involve close coordination with the transplant team to adjust antifungal therapy and possibly modify immunosuppressive medications to manage the infection effectively. Monitoring of infection markers and imaging studies will be necessary to assess response to treatment. Patient education on recognizing symptoms of infection and the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen will be emphasized. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust treatment as needed.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I understand you've been brought to the emergency department due to sudden weakness and respiratory distress. Can you tell me more about how you're feeling?
Patient: Yeah, I suddenly felt really weak and it's hard to breathe. My consciousness feels confused too.
Doctor: I see. We've noticed that you have areflexic acute flaccid paralysis present on all four extremities. We've conducted some laboratory tests to better understand your condition. Your erythrocyte sedimentation rate is slightly elevated at 21 mm/h, compared to the average of 15 mm/h.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: Your blood count, acetylcholine receptor antibody, thyroid function tests, and other laboratory findings are all within the normal range. However, there are no cells present in your cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and the CSF protein is high at 65 mg/dL.
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean, doc?
Doctor: These findings could suggest some sort of neurological issue. On the second day of your hospitalization, you developed bilateral peripheral facial paralysis. Additionally, nerve conduction studies showed a decrease in the sensory and motor action potentials of your upper extremities, with increased distal latencies.
Patient: That sounds serious.
Doctor: It is quite concerning. We also couldn't obtain any combined muscle action potential (CMAP) from your bilateral peroneal-tibial nerves or sural nerve sensory action potential. To help you, we decided to perform plasma exchange every other day, for a total of three times due to your respiratory distress.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: Unfortunately, you developed resistant hypotension as an autonomic dysfunction, along with pulmonary infections. We tried our best to control the hypotension, but it persisted.
Patient: Oh no...
Doctor: I'm sorry to inform you that your condition worsened and you experienced cardiac arrest on the sixth day of your hospitalization. Despite our efforts, we were unable to save you.
Patient's Family: We appreciate your efforts, doctor. We understand that you did everything you could. Thank you for trying.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of weakness, respiratory distress, and confusion. The patient reported feeling extremely weak and having difficulty breathing.
O: On examination, the patient exhibited areflexic acute flaccid paralysis in all four extremities. Laboratory tests revealed an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 21 mm/h (normal: up to 15 mm/h). Blood count, acetylcholine receptor antibody, and thyroid function tests were within normal limits. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis showed no cells and elevated protein at 65 mg/dL. Nerve conduction studies indicated decreased sensory and motor action potentials in the upper extremities with increased distal latencies, and absence of combined muscle action potential from bilateral peroneal-tibial nerves and sural nerve sensory action potential. The patient developed bilateral peripheral facial paralysis on the second day of hospitalization. The patient also experienced resistant hypotension and pulmonary infections, leading to cardiac arrest on the sixth day despite medical interventions.
A: The primary diagnosis is Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), suggested by the clinical presentation of acute flaccid paralysis, areflexia, elevated CSF protein without cells, and abnormal nerve conduction studies. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute neuropathy, but these are less likely given the findings. Complications included autonomic dysfunction manifesting as resistant hypotension, pulmonary infections, and ultimately, cardiac arrest.
P: The treatment plan included plasma exchange every other day, totaling three sessions, aimed at managing the presumed GBS and associated respiratory distress. Management of autonomic dysfunction and pulmonary infections was attempted, though the patient ultimately succumbed to complications. Future recommendations for similar cases would include early and aggressive management of GBS and its complications, close monitoring of autonomic functions, and timely intervention for infections to prevent fatal outcomes.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having some right-sided loin pain and I noticed some microscopic hematuria, but I don't have any urinary symptoms.
Doctor: I see, let's run some routine blood tests to check your renal function and perform an ultrasound scan of your urinary tract to see if there might be any issues.
Patient: Okay, that sounds good.
[After tests and scan]
Doctor: Your blood tests show a derangement in your renal function and the ultrasound scan revealed right-sided hydronephrosis. We need to do a further computed tomography (CT) scan of your kidneys, ureters, and bladder to get a clearer picture of what's going on.
Patient: Alright, let's do it.
[After CT scan]
Doctor: The CT scan showed a dilatation of the ureter up to the vesicoureteric junction with an associated tight stricture. We'll need to perform a right rigid ureteroscopy, ureteric biopsy, and ureteric stent insertion to get a better understanding of the issue.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
[After procedure]
Doctor: The histology report from the biopsy shows that you have transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter. Initially, we didn't perform any neuroendocrine markers because the tumor didn't show any classical signs of a carcinoid tumor or a well-differentiated small cell carcinoma. However, further examination revealed an atypical carcinoid pattern.
Patient: Oh no, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We did some further imaging of your chest and fortunately, we didn't find any distant metastases. Our plan is to perform a right laparoscopic nephroureterectomy and open excision of the bladder cuff to remove the tumor.
Patient: I'm glad there's a plan in place. Let's do what needs to be done.
[After surgery]
Doctor: The surgery went well. The tumor in your ureter was about 18 mm long, and we were able to achieve a clear resection margin of at least 4 mm. Microscopy of the ureteric specimen showed a positive immunohistochemical stain with CD56, a common neuroendocrine marker. Staining with other neuroendocrine markers was weakly positive. The tumor was intermediate to high grade, with a high Ki-67 proliferation index of 25 to 30%. We didn't find any associated carcinoma in situ or definite lymphovascular invasion.
Patient: That's a relief. What does that mean for my recovery?
Doctor: The tumor infiltrated through the muscle into the periureteric fat, which is a T3 stage. Your kidney showed patchy lymphocytic infiltrates, indicating mild interstitial nephritis, but there was no tumor infiltration into the kidney or the urothelium covering the renal pelvis.
Patient: So, what are the next steps?
Doctor: You made an unremarkable recovery from the surgery. As you remain well and your chromogranin levels are only mildly elevated and stable, the oncologist decided that there's no need for adjuvant therapy at this time. We'll continue to monitor your condition closely.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate all your help.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient presented with right-sided loin pain and microscopic hematuria, without any urinary symptoms. The patient's history includes undergoing diagnostic tests and a surgical procedure for the identified condition.
O: Initial blood tests indicated renal function derangement. Ultrasound showed right-sided hydronephrosis. CT scan revealed a dilatation of the ureter up to the vesicoureteric junction with a tight stricture. Histology from a ureteric biopsy diagnosed transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter, with immunohistochemical staining positive for CD56 and weakly positive for other neuroendocrine markers. The tumor was intermediate to high grade with a Ki-67 proliferation index of 25 to 30%. Surgery achieved a clear resection margin of 4 mm, and the tumor was staged as T3. Post-operative recovery was unremarkable.
A: The primary diagnosis is transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter, stage T3. The differential diagnosis initially considered included other forms of urothelial carcinoma or a neuroendocrine tumor, which was ruled out based on further testing. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical resection and absence of distant metastases or lymphovascular invasion.
P: The patient underwent right laparoscopic nephroureterectomy and open excision of the bladder cuff. Post-surgery, the plan includes close monitoring without adjuvant therapy as the chromogranin levels are only mildly elevated and stable. Regular follow-ups with oncology are scheduled to monitor for any recurrence or progression of the disease. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms immediately.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm glad you're here today for a follow-up regarding your long-standing daytime sleepiness. Can you describe your sleepiness episodes and how they affect your daily life?
Patient: Yeah, I often experience sudden onsets of sleep, even while standing up, and sometimes I lose up to 30 minutes. It's been really frustrating.
Doctor: I see. Do you ever have cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, or sleep paralysis during these episodes?
Patient: No, I don't have any of those.
Doctor: Okay. I have your initial evaluation report from 1993, which indicated that you had 32 awakenings, 2 apnea/hypopnea spells, and a mean sleep onset of 5.9 minutes during the sleep studies. You were also observed to enter REM sleep in at least two and possibly four of the five naps. Did anything change since then?
Patient: I moved and went to your sleep disorders center in 2004 with the same complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness. I wasn't on any specific treatment at that time.
Doctor: Thanks for the information. Did you experience any sleepwalking episodes during this time?
Patient: Yes, I had some episodes where I was walking on the roof of a chemical plant where I worked or even smoking a cigarette on my front porch.
Doctor: I see that an overnight polysomnogram (PSG) and multiple sleep latency test (MSLT) were performed in 2004. There was no significant sleep-disordered breathing, abnormal increase in muscle tone, or unusual activity during REM or non-REM sleep. Sleep occurred on all four nap opportunities, with a mean sleep latency of 10 minutes and no sleep onset REM periods. Were you given any treatments after these tests?
Patient: Yes, I was given stimulant medications and advised to extend my nocturnal sleep period. Methylphenidate at 20 mg per day didn't help much, and higher doses up to 60 mg per day made me irritable and angry. I also tried modafinil, but I couldn't tolerate it because of gastrointestinal effects.
Doctor: I understand. I have the results of the repeat PSG and MSLT performed in 2008. The PSG showed excellent sleep efficiency at 96.5%, normal REM latency of 93.5 minutes, REM sleep comprising 16.8% of total sleep time, and normal slow wave sleep. MSLT results are also within normal limits. Based on this information, we'll work on finding a new treatment plan for your daytime sleepiness. We'll continue to monitor your progress and make adjustments as needed.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help and hope we can find a solution to my daytime sleepiness soon.
ground_truth_soap:

The patient denies experiencing cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, or sleep paralysis. The patient has a history of sleepwalking, including potentially dangerous situations. Previous treatments with stimulant medications were not effective or not tolerated due to side effects.
O: Initial sleep studies from 1993 showed frequent awakenings, mild sleep apnea, and rapid entry into REM sleep. A 2004 polysomnogram (PSG) and multiple sleep latency test (MSLT) showed no significant sleep-disordered breathing or abnormal muscle tone, with a mean sleep latency of 10 minutes. Repeat PSG in 2008 demonstrated excellent sleep efficiency (96.5%), normal REM latency (93.5 minutes), and normal slow wave sleep. MSLT results were within normal limits.
A: The primary diagnosis is idiopathic hypersomnia given the excessive daytime sleepiness and absence of significant sleep-disordered breathing or narcolepsy-specific findings (e.g., sleep onset REM periods). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypersomnia, such as sleep apnea or medication effects, though these seem less likely given the test results and history.
P: The management plan will focus on exploring alternative treatments for idiopathic hypersomnia. Consideration will be given to non-stimulant wakefulness-promoting agents and adjustments to sleep hygiene. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to the new treatment plan and make adjustments as necessary. Education on sleep hygiene and lifestyle modifications to improve sleep quality and daytime alertness will be provided. Referral to a sleep specialist may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

Patient: Hi, I'm a 19-year-old female and I recently got a dental implant. I went to my orthodontist because I was having some problems with it.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about the complications you've experienced?
Patient: Well, my jaw has been hurting, and it feels like there's something wrong with the implant area.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. We performed a biopsy to better understand what's going on, and it confirmed that you have central giant cell granuloma (CGCG) of the jaw.
Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. What can we do about it?
Doctor: Don't worry, we've started you on a treatment called denosumab. You'll be receiving 120 mg monthly. It should help with your condition.
Patient: Okay, that's good to know. How will we keep track of my progress?
Doctor: We'll be conducting surveillance to monitor your condition. This will include imaging and a repeat biopsy at the 1-year treatment mark.
Patient: So, I'll have to wait a year to know if the treatment is working?
Doctor: Yes, we need to give the treatment time to show its effects. But we'll be keeping a close eye on your progress throughout this period.
Patient: Alright, I understand. Is there anything else I need to be aware of or do during this time?
Doctor: Just make sure to attend your monthly appointments for denosumab and report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. We'll provide you with further instructions as needed.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me. I'll make sure to follow your advice.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out. Take care and see you at your next appointment.
ground_truth_soap:

O: A biopsy was performed, confirming the diagnosis of central giant cell granuloma (CGCG) of the jaw. The patient has been prescribed denosumab, with a dosage of 120 mg monthly.
A: The primary diagnosis is central giant cell granuloma of the jaw, confirmed by biopsy. The patient has started treatment with denosumab, which is appropriate for managing CGCG.
P: The management plan includes monthly administration of denosumab 120 mg. Surveillance will be conducted to monitor the patient's condition, including imaging and a repeat biopsy at the 1-year treatment mark. The patient is advised to attend all monthly appointments and report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Further instructions will be provided as needed, and the patient is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns.

Doctor: I see. Based on your presentation, it's important that we conduct a thorough examination. Let me examine your abdomen.
Patient: Sure, go ahead.
Doctor: (After examination) It seems you have pain and tenderness on the right side of your abdomen. We'll need to run some clinical, laboratory, and radiological tests to determine the cause.
Patient: Okay, I hope it's nothing serious.
Doctor: (After tests) We've found that you've tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 through a PCR test of your nasopharyngeal swab. In addition, based on your symptoms and our examination, we suspect that you may have appendicitis.
Patient: Oh no, what will happen now?
Doctor: We will start you on an empiric intravenous antimicrobial treatment with cefotaxime and metronidazole to help fight the infection. Additionally, you'll need to undergo a laparoscopic appendectomy in the operating room to remove your appendix.
Patient: How soon will I have the surgery?
Doctor: We will take you to the operating room as soon as possible, as this is an emergency case.
Patient: Alright then, I hope everything goes well.
Doctor: Rest assured, our team will take good care of you. We perform appendectomies routinely, and we'll monitor you closely during the procedure and afterwards.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

O: Physical examination revealed tenderness and pain on the right side of the abdomen. Laboratory tests confirmed a positive SARS-CoV-2 PCR test from a nasopharyngeal swab. No additional lab values or imaging results provided.
A: The primary diagnosis is appendicitis, with a differential diagnosis of a gastrointestinal manifestation of COVID-19 due to the positive SARS-CoV-2 test. The presence of right-sided abdominal tenderness and systemic symptoms such as vomiting support the diagnosis of appendicitis.
P: The patient will be started on empiric intravenous antimicrobial treatment with cefotaxime and metronidazole. A laparoscopic appendectomy is scheduled urgently to remove the inflamed appendix. Post-operative care will include monitoring for complications and managing COVID-19 symptoms as necessary. The patient will be educated about the procedures and expected post-operative course.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that your male infant was referred to our intensive care unit from a peripheral facility. Can you please describe the symptoms he has been experiencing?
Parent: Yes, he has had one day of progressively worsening difficulty in breathing and feeding. He also had multiple convulsions of generalized tonic clonic nature.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Upon examination, we found that he was dyspneic, afebrile, and tachycardic, with cold extremities, weak pulses, and a delayed capillary refill of 4 seconds. His blood pressure was 98/64 mmHg, and his blood sugar was 14.4 mmol l–1. We also performed an arterial blood gas test, which showed a mixed metabolic/respiratory acidosis with a pH of 7.1, hypercapnia (pCO2 55 mmHg), and decreased bicarbonate levels (20 mEq l–1). His white cell count was 15.6 × 109 µl–1, largely consisting of neutrophils (76%), and he had a reactive thrombocytosis (605 × 109 µl–1) and an international normalized ratio (INR) of 1.24. His chest radiograph appeared normal. Can you tell me more about his medical history?
Parent: Well, he had an uneventful natal and postnatal period, but he has been suffering from nasal congestion for the past 3 weeks. We've been treating it with nasal saline drops, antihistamines, antibiotics, and antipyretics.
Doctor: Thank you for that information. In the ICU, we immediately intubated him with an endotracheal tube that is 3.5 mm in diameter and 11 cm in length. We also started him on broad-spectrum antibiotics, including ceftriaxone and clarithromycin, for severe pneumonia and sepsis. Additionally, he was given phenytoin and morphine.
Doctor: We also noticed a firm, smooth, immobile left submandibular mass, extending to the neck levels II-V. We performed a CT scan, which revealed a 27 mm × 47 mm × 42 mm parapharyngeal/paravertebral cystic mass that is obliterating the oropharyngeal airway. Acute left LST was also discovered and confirmed via an MRI.
Parent: Oh, that sounds serious. What are the next steps in his treatment?
Doctor: We have started him on low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) at a dosage of 1 mg/kg–1. Additionally, we performed an ultrasound-guided aspiration, which revealed pus. We drained 20 ml of fluid and flushed the cavity with 40 mg of gentamicin.
Doctor: We will continue to closely monitor your son's condition and adjust his treatment as needed. Our team will do everything we can to ensure that he receives the best possible care while he is in the ICU.
Parent: Thank you, Doctor. We appreciate all your efforts in helping our son.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient, a male infant, presented with one day of progressively worsening difficulty in breathing and feeding, along with multiple generalized tonic-clonic convulsions. The parent also reported a 3-week history of nasal congestion treated with nasal saline drops, antihistamines, antibiotics, and antipyretics.
O: On examination, the infant was dyspneic, afebrile, and tachycardic with cold extremities, weak pulses, and a delayed capillary refill of 4 seconds. Vital signs included a blood pressure of 98/64 mmHg and a blood sugar level of 14.4 mmol/L. Arterial blood gas analysis showed mixed metabolic/respiratory acidosis (pH 7.1, pCO2 55 mmHg, bicarbonate 20 mEq/L). Laboratory tests revealed a white cell count of 15.6 × 10^9/µL with 76% neutrophils, thrombocytosis (605 × 10^9/µL), and an INR of 1.24. Chest radiograph was normal. A CT scan and MRI identified a 27 mm × 47 mm × 42 mm parapharyngeal/paravertebral cystic mass obstructing the oropharyngeal airway and acute left LST. Ultrasound-guided aspiration of the mass yielded pus.

Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress and convulsions in infants.
P: The patient was intubated and started on broad-spectrum antibiotics (ceftriaxone and clarithromycin), anticonvulsants (phenytoin), and analgesics (morphine). Treatment for the cystic mass included drainage and flushing with gentamicin. Enoxaparin was initiated for acute left LST. Ongoing management will include close monitoring in the ICU, adjustments to therapy as needed, and further diagnostic evaluations to assess the progression or resolution of the identified conditions.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi, I understand that you've presented to our hand and peripheral nerve clinic 4 months after an attempted Nexplanon® removal from your left arm. Can you tell me more about that experience?
Patient: Yeah, my nurse practitioner tried to remove it, but neither of us was able to feel the Nexplanon® before the removal. They didn't do any imaging studies to confirm its location.
Doctor: I see. So, what happened during the removal attempt?
Patient: They injected some local anesthetic and made a small incision at the site of insertion. But they couldn't find the Nexplanon® right away. After exploring the area, the NP grabbed something in my arm, and I felt an "electric shock" sensation that went down to my medial elbow as they pulled on it.
Doctor: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. What happened after the removal attempt?
Patient: I had complete numbness in my small and ring fingers. I went back to my NP for a follow-up, but the numbness didn't improve over time. I also started to notice my hand muscles wasting away and my grip getting weaker.
Doctor: That's concerning. Did your NP order any tests to investigate this issue?
Patient: Yes, they ordered a nerve conduction study almost 4 months after the attempted removal. The results showed a 50% loss of ulnar nerve function.
Doctor: Based on your presentation, it appears that you have a severe, chronic ulnar nerve injury. On examination, I can see the classic signs: wasting of the ulnar nerve-innervated intrinsic muscles of your hand, a claw position of your ring and small fingers, and dense numbness in an ulnar sensory nerve distribution. I also noticed a well-healed incision with surrounding scar tissue from the extraction attempt. Can you feel the Nexplanon® in your arm now?
Patient: No, I still can't feel it.
Doctor: We took some X-rays, and they showed the radio-opaque Nexplanon® at the junction of the proximal and middle thirds of your humeral shaft, with the most distal end 16.5 cm proximal to the medial epicondyle.
Patient: Oh, I see. What does this mean for me, and what are the next steps?
Doctor: Given your history and the current state of your ulnar nerve injury, we need to discuss your options for treatment and recovery. We will also need to plan the proper removal of the Nexplanon® to avoid any further complications. I'll consult with my colleagues and come up with the best course of action for your situation.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
ground_truth_soap:
S: Patient reports a failed Nexplanon® removal attempt from the left arm 4 months ago, performed without prior imaging to locate the implant. During the procedure, the patient experienced an "electric shock" sensation and subsequently developed complete numbness in the small and ring fingers, along with muscle wasting and weakened grip strength. A nerve conduction study indicated a 50% loss of ulnar nerve function.
O: Physical examination shows wasting of the ulnar nerve-innervated intrinsic hand muscles, a claw position of the ring and small fingers, and dense numbness in an ulnar sensory nerve distribution. A well-healed incision with surrounding scar tissue is noted at the extraction site. X-rays reveal the Nexplanon® located at the junction of the proximal and middle thirds of the humeral shaft, 16.5 cm proximal to the medial epicondyle.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe, chronic ulnar nerve injury secondary to traumatic handling during the Nexplanon® removal attempt. The misplaced Nexplanon® complicates the clinical picture.
P: Plan to consult with a multidisciplinary team to discuss the best approach for managing the ulnar nerve injury and safely removing the Nexplanon®. Educate the patient on the prognosis and potential recovery options, including surgical and non-surgical interventions. Schedule follow-up appointments to monitor nerve recovery and discuss the outcomes of the consultations. Ensure patient understands the importance of adhering to the proposed management plan to optimize recovery and prevent further complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. I understand you have a history of CTEPH and are here for a PTE procedure. How are you feeling today?
Patient: Hi, Dr. Smith. I'm a bit nervous but ready to get this done.
Doctor: I understand. During the rewarming process following your PTE, we noticed bright red blood in your airway. We performed a bronchoscopy and found that there was bleeding from your right lung.
Patient: Oh no, that sounds scary.
Doctor: It was concerning, but we attempted to control the bleeding by placing a right-sided Arndt endobronchial blocker. Unfortunately, due to copious bleeding, our first attempt was unsuccessful.
Patient: What happened next?
Doctor: We exchanged your 8.0 mm single lumen ETT for a 9 mm single lumen ETT. Then, we were able to successfully place a right-sided 9Fr Arndt endobronchial blocker with the aid of a 6.0 mm outer diameter therapeutic bronchoscope. This helped contain the bleeding.
Patient: That's a relief.
Doctor: We continued weaning you off the cardiopulmonary bypass, and everything went well. You were then transferred to the ICU for close monitoring.
Patient: So, what's next for me?
Doctor: Unfortunately, your postoperative course has been complicated by renal failure, reintubation for hemoptysis, and poor neurologic recovery. Due to these multiple complications, we have been discussing the best course of action with your family.
Patient's family: Doctor, what options do we have for him?
Doctor: At this point, we are considering initiating comfort only measures to ensure that he is as comfortable as possible during this difficult time.
Patient's family: We understand. We want him to be comfortable.
Doctor: I'm sorry to say, but despite our best efforts, the patient expired on postoperative day 20. Our condolences to the family, and we will continue to provide support as needed.
ground_truth_soap:

He reported feeling nervous but ready for the procedure. Postoperatively, he experienced complications including renal failure, reintubation for hemoptysis, and poor neurologic recovery.
O: During the rewarming process post-PTE, bright red blood was noted in the patient's airway. A bronchoscopy revealed bleeding from the right lung. Initial attempts to control the bleeding with a right-sided Arndt endobronchial blocker were unsuccessful due to copious bleeding. The patient's 8.0 mm single lumen endotracheal tube (ETT) was exchanged for a 9 mm ETT, and a right-sided 9Fr Arndt endobronchial blocker was successfully placed with the aid of a 6.0 mm outer diameter therapeutic bronchoscope. The patient was weaned off cardiopulmonary bypass and transferred to the ICU for close monitoring.
A: The primary diagnosis is postoperative complications following PTE in a patient with CTEPH. These complications include acute renal failure, recurrent hemoptysis requiring reintubation, and poor neurologic recovery. The prognosis is poor, indicated by the transition to comfort-only measures and subsequent expiration on postoperative day 20.
P: The management plan included aggressive attempts to control pulmonary bleeding and support organ function postoperatively. Despite these efforts, the patient's condition deteriorated, leading to the decision to initiate comfort-only measures. Discussions with the family were held to ensure understanding and consent for this approach. Support and condolences were offered to the family following the patient's death.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there! I see you recently presented 2 weeks after an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy for non-perforated acute appendicitis. How have you been feeling since the surgery?
Patient: Well, I've been having some issues with my urinary frequency. It's reduced to just twice per day and I'm experiencing prolonged hesitancy.
Doctor: I see. Can you describe your micturition stream for me?
Patient: Initially, it was weak and slow, but now it has become interrupted. Straining doesn't seem to help make the stream stronger.
Doctor: Alright. Have you ever suffered from urinary tract infections (UTIs) or constipation before?
Patient: No, I've never had any UTIs or constipation. I usually open my bowels daily.
Doctor: I understand you also had an episode of acute cystitis 2 months later. How was that treated?
Patient: I completely lost my ability to void, so I was put on an indwelling Foley urinary catheter. My cystitis was successfully treated with antibiotics.
Doctor: And what happened after the catheter was removed?
Patient: After every attempt to remove it, I had to be catheterized again, and they registered between 300 to 1200 mL of urine volume.
Doctor: How did that make you feel?
Patient: I lost the urge to urinate and only felt a dull pain in the suprapubic region and right iliac fossa when my bladder was extremely distended.
Doctor: I see you were referred to a tertiary center to determine the cause of your urinary retention. What were the results of your examinations?
Patient: They examined me and found normal clinical findings. They also did an abdominal and pelvic ultrasound scan but didn't find any obvious pathology. A pediatric neurologist checked me out and found nothing abnormal.
Doctor: Did they perform any additional tests, like magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), electromyography (EMG), somatosensory-evoked potentials (SEP) of the tibial nerve, electroencephalogram (EEG), or a lumbar puncture?
Patient: Yes, they did all of those tests, but they still didn't find any pathology.
Doctor: What about any gynecological examinations?
Patient: The gynecologist found multiple follicular cysts on my ovaries bilaterally but nothing that would explain my urinary retention.
Doctor: Our pediatric urologist performed an examination under general anesthesia. Have you been informed about the results?
Patient: They mentioned something about a free calibration of the urethra up to 26F and normal findings on cystoscopy.
Doctor: Yes, that's correct. The videourodynamic study (VUDS) showed an asensitive and hypotonic bladder. They had to stop the bladder filling at 360 mL due to your discomfort. The maximum intravesical pressure achieved was 11 cmH2O. Did you experience any discomfort when they pulled the urodynamic catheter out?
Patient: Yes, I felt some discomfort during that part of the procedure.
Doctor: Thank you for all the information. We will continue to monitor your condition and work on finding the cause of your urinary retention. In the meantime, please keep us updated on any changes in your symptoms.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient, who underwent an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy for non-perforated acute appendicitis two weeks ago, reports decreased urinary frequency (twice per day) with prolonged hesitancy, weak and interrupted micturition stream, and no improvement with straining. The patient denies previous history of urinary tract infections or constipation and reports daily bowel movements. Post-appendectomy, the patient experienced acute cystitis treated with antibiotics and required repeated catheterization due to inability to void, with urine volumes ranging from 300 to 1200 mL. The patient also reports loss of the urge to urinate and dull pain in the suprapubic region and right iliac fossa when the bladder is extremely distended.
O: Physical and ultrasound examinations at a tertiary center showed no obvious pathology. Neurological evaluations including MRI, EMG, SEP, EEG, and lumbar puncture revealed no abnormalities. Gynecological examination identified bilateral ovarian follicular cysts but no findings related to urinary retention. Pediatric urology assessment under general anesthesia showed free urethral calibration up to 26F and normal cystoscopy findings. Videourodynamic study indicated an asensitive and hypotonic bladder with maximum intravesical pressure of 11 cmH2O, and bladder filling was stopped at 360 mL due to discomfort.
A: The primary diagnosis is urinary retention with an asensitive and hypotonic bladder, post-surgical. Differential diagnoses could include neurogenic bladder, though current evaluations have not supported this. The presence of ovarian follicular cysts appears incidental and unrelated to the urinary symptoms.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's urinary function and symptoms. Plan for regular follow-up visits to reassess bladder function and response to any interventions. Consider consultation with a neurologist specializing in autonomic dysfunction given the lack of findings from standard neurological tests and the nature of bladder dysfunction. Educate the patient on recognizing signs of urinary tract infections and bladder distension. Discuss potential need for intermittent catheterization if spontaneous voiding does not improve. Encourage the patient to maintain adequate hydration and report any new symptoms or changes in urinary habits.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I'm a 45-year-old English teacher, and I've been suffering from right knee pain for about a year now. It got worse eight months ago.
Doctor: I see. Can you recall any trauma or injury that might have led to this pain?
Patient: No, I don't remember any specific trauma.
Doctor: What kind of treatment have you received so far?
Patient: I underwent conservative treatment at another clinic for six months. They prescribed intermittent non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs, some injections, but I don't know the exact drug, and physical therapy.
Doctor: Okay, how would you describe your pain and any other symptoms?
Patient: I have severe anterior knee pain when climbing stairs or squatting. Also, I've noticed a cystic mass in the posterior aspect of my knee joint that's been increasing in size.
Doctor: Let's perform a physical examination. *After examining* I found mild swelling and effusion in your right knee, but no localized heat sense. Painful crepitation and moderate tenderness are present during knee motion. There's also a large, non-tender cystic mass in the posterior aspect of the right knee joint. I noticed crepitation in your left knee too, but you mentioned no discomfort on the left side, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct. No pain on the left side at all.
Doctor: I also observed that there's no cystic lesion on your left knee. Your right infrapatellar region is larger than normal and feels firm. Your passive full knee range of motion is possible, but painful. There's no tenderness on your tibial tubercle or patella.
Patient: Hmm, what do you think is causing this?
Doctor: I've reviewed your plain radiographic examination, and it shows a large ossicle beneath the patellar tendon and inside the infrapatellar fat pad in your right knee. Interestingly, there's a similar-sized ossicle in your left knee, partially fused to the hypertrophied tibial tuberosity.
Patient: What about the MRI results?
Doctor: Your right knee magnetic resonance images show a 3.8 x 1.3 x 3.0 cm sized, well-circumscribed ossicle. There are several smaller ossicles near the tibial tubercle as well. Inflammatory changes in synovium, infrapatellar fat pad, and patellar tendon are also visible. A reactive bone marrow edema was found at the anterior aspect of the tibial condyle.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: Based on your symptoms and test results, we'll discuss a treatment plan that may include medication, additional therapy, or even surgery if necessary. We will closely monitor your progress and make adjustments as needed. It's important to follow up regularly and report any changes in your symptoms.
Patient: Alright, thank you for your help, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll work together to get you back on your feet as soon as possible.

The presence of a cystic mass and ossicles suggests a complex intra-articular pathology, possibly involving the synovium or infrapatellar fat pad.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I'm experiencing sudden epigastric pain, and I feel like I'm in shock.
Doctor: I see. In that case, let me check your vital signs. We need to find out what's causing this shock. Have you had any recent medical issues?
Patient: Yes, I was hospitalized a month ago in your department and underwent a patch repair for a gastric ulcer perforation.
Doctor: Alright, let's perform a contrast-enhanced CT scan to get more information. 
(After CT scan)
Doctor: The CT scan revealed a retroperitoneal hematoma in your pancreatic head, aneurysm formation in the PDA, and extraluminal compression to the celiac trunk. Extravasation was also detected around the aneurysm in the PDA, but no liquid was retained in your peritoneal cavity.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. What should we do?
Doctor: We will perform an emergent IVR for hemostasis to address the retroperitoneal hemorrhage from the ruptured PDA aneurysm. Arteriography of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) will be done through a sheath introduced in your right femoral artery.
Patient: Okay, go ahead.
(After the procedure)
Doctor: The imaging of the SMA revealed the development of several collaterals in your pancreatic head, and the common and proper hepatic arteries were imaged via these collaterals. The aneurysm in your PDA had leakage of the contrast-enhanced agent with a diameter of 9.3 mm. We have completed the IVR hemostasis by performing PDA coil embolization.
Patient: So, what's next?
Doctor: We will conduct SMA arteriography to see the other collaterals perfusing your proper hepatic artery. After the IVR therapy, we will monitor your blood chemical analysis for several weeks to ensure that your transaminase level is not elevated and hepatic infarction is negative.
Patient: Got it. And what about the obstruction caused by the hematoma?
Doctor: We observed obstruction of the duodenal passage resulting from the hematoma for a few weeks. However, bypass surgery was not required as the obstruction was completely relieved as the hematoma was naturally and gradually absorbed.
Patient: That's a relief. What could have caused all this?
Doctor: In your case, collateral perfusion pathways from the SMA developed to compensate for the reduced CA blood flow due to MAL compression, and the aneurysm might have been generated in the PDA due to the abnormal changes in hemodynamic flow. Preservative treatment did not appear to relieve the CA compression. Additionally, we considered that new aneurysms may form following new collateral circulation after IVR hemostasis.
Patient: I see. Thank you for explaining everything, doctor. I'll make sure to follow up on my treatments and tests.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please make sure to attend your follow-up appointments, and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns. Take care!
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient reports sudden epigastric pain and feelings of shock. He has a history of hospitalization for a gastric ulcer perforation, which was treated with a patch repair one month ago.
O: Vital signs were taken, though specific values are not provided. A contrast-enhanced CT scan showed a retroperitoneal hematoma in the pancreatic head, aneurysm formation in the pancreaticoduodenal artery (PDA), and extraluminal compression to the celiac trunk with extravasation around the PDA aneurysm. No liquid retention in the peritoneal cavity was noted. Post-procedure imaging indicated a 9.3 mm aneurysm in the PDA with leakage of contrast agent. SMA arteriography revealed several collaterals in the pancreatic head and imaging of the common and proper hepatic arteries.
A: The primary diagnosis is a ruptured PDA aneurysm with retroperitoneal hemorrhage and celiac trunk compression. Differential diagnoses include complications from previous gastric surgery and potential hepatic infarction due to altered vascular flow. The prognosis depends on the effectiveness of the IVR hemostasis and the patient's response to ongoing monitoring.
P: The patient underwent emergent IVR for hemostasis, including PDA coil embolization. Plans include further SMA arteriography to assess collateral perfusion to the hepatic artery and monitoring of blood chemical analysis for several weeks to check transaminase levels and rule out hepatic infarction. The patient was advised to attend follow-up appointments and monitor for any new symptoms. Education on the importance of follow-up and adherence to treatment was provided.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I understand you're a 13-year-old girl who has been experiencing abdominal pain and bloody stool. Can you tell me more about how long this has been happening and how it's been progressing?
Patient: Yeah, I started having abdominal pain about 3 months ago. At first, it wasn't too bad and would come and go, so I didn't see a doctor. But lately, the pain has gotten worse, and I've been having bloody stool more often.
Doctor: I see. We performed an imaging study and it showed that there's a mass, including a fecalith, occupying your pelvic and right lower abdominal cavity (Fig.). Based on this, we made a preoperative diagnosis of an acute appendicitis with an appendiceal mass (Fig.). We've already done drainage of the abscess and an appendectomy.
Patient: Oh, okay. So what did you find during the procedure?
Doctor: Although the body of your appendix looked intact, as well as your ileum and cecum, the histopathological examination revealed PAA in the tip of the resected appendix. Because of this, we have planned a radical operation for the residual tumor of PAA in your pelvic cavity.
Patient: What does that operation involve?
Doctor: It involves a whole mass resection and ileocecal resection with lymph node dissection. In the first operation, we speculate that we removed the body of your appendix but left most of the mass and the tip of the appendix. So in the second operation, we will remove the mass that was derived from the tip of your appendix.
Patient: Will you need to remove any other organs?
Doctor: Unfortunately, yes. The masses are tightly adherent with infiltration into your sigmoid colon, uterus, and right ovary. We will need to remove these organs, and then perform a subsequent sigmoid colostomy (Fig.). However, we will preserve your left ovary to maintain your fertility.
Patient: What were the results of the pathological examination?
Doctor: The pathological findings demonstrated negative margins and no lymph node invasions. Your final pathological stage is pT4(SI)N0M0, stage II based on TNM-7th edition 2009.
Patient: How was my recovery after the operation?
Doctor: Your postoperative course was uneventful, which is a good sign.
Patient: Did I receive any additional treatment after the operation?
Doctor: Yes, you received chemotherapy consisting of 6 cycles of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), leucovorin (LV), and oxaliplatin (mFOLFOX6), followed by 6 cycles of simplified LV and 5-FU (sLV5FU2).
Patient: How am I doing now?
Doctor: You're doing well on follow-up, and there has been no progression of your condition. We'll continue to monitor your health closely to ensure your ongoing well-being.
ground_truth_soap:
S: A 13-year-old female patient reports a 3-month history of intermittent abdominal pain which has recently worsened, accompanied by frequent episodes of bloody stool.
O: Imaging studies revealed a mass with a fecalith in the pelvic and right lower abdominal cavity, leading to a preoperative diagnosis of acute appendicitis with an appendiceal mass. Histopathological examination post-appendectomy identified pseudomyxoma appendicei (PAA) at the tip of the appendix. The patient underwent an appendectomy and drainage of an abscess. Further surgery involved resection of the mass, ileocecal resection, and lymph node dissection, with additional removal of the sigmoid colon, uterus, and right ovary due to infiltration. Pathological examination showed negative margins, no lymph node invasions, and a final stage of pT4(SI)N0M0, stage II. Postoperative recovery was uneventful. The patient received chemotherapy including 6 cycles of mFOLFOX6 and 6 cycles of sLV5FU2.
A: The primary diagnosis is pseudomyxoma appendicei (PAA) with complications including infiltration into adjacent organs necessitating extensive surgical intervention. The patient's condition is currently stable with no progression post-treatment.
P: The management plan includes ongoing close monitoring and follow-up to detect any signs of recurrence or complications. The patient will continue with regular medical reviews to assess her recovery and response to the chemotherapy. Further education on the signs of potential complications and lifestyle adjustments post-surgery will be provided to ensure optimal recovery and maintenance of health.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having some problems for the past two years. I noticed a hard lesion in my anal canal, but I haven't gotten it officially diagnosed or treated yet.
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any other health issues during this time?
Patient: Yes, about ten months ago, I had a cholecystectomy due to cholelithiasis.
Doctor: Did the doctors find anything during the perioperative diagnostic examination?
Patient: They did. They found some suspicious lesions in my anal canal and some enlarged pelvic lymph nodes.
Doctor: What about your medical history? Do you have any comorbidities or a family history of malignancies?
Patient: I have gout, and my Karnofsky performance status is 90. I've never had radiotherapy, but I do have a second-degree family history of malignancies.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. Let's discuss the results of your digital rectal examination. It identified mild prostatomegaly and a palpable suspicious nodule in the left prostate lobe. There were no signs of extracapsular extension. Additionally, a large ulcerated mass was found in the dorsal anal canal wall, but no lymphadenopathies in the inguinal region.
Patient: Oh, I see. What about the colonoscopy?
Doctor: The colonoscopy confirmed the presence of a suspicious lesion on the posterior anal canal, extending up to the anorectal junction.
Patient: And the MRI results?
Doctor: The magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed an infiltrative lesion of the anal canal with a maximum diameter of 3.2 cm, a high-grade suspicion of sphincter infiltration, and two enlarged lymphadenopathies in the mesorectum and right internal iliac region, both with a maximal diameter of 2 cm. These are suspicious of tumor metastases.
Patient: What about that area in the prostate?
Doctor: The MRI also found an area with a maximal diameter of 2 cm within the left prostate basis with restricted diffusion and a lower apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) than the surrounding healthy prostate tissue. It appeared hypointense on ADC maps but hyperintense on diffusion-weighted maps.
Patient: What did the biopsies show?
Doctor: The biopsies confirmed a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal and a moderately differentiated prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3 + 4) in both lobes.
Patient: Is there anything else I should know?
Doctor: You tested negative for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), and your carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels were also assessed.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything to me, Doctor.
ground_truth_soap:

He reports a past medical history significant for cholecystectomy due to cholelithiasis ten months ago. During perioperative examination, suspicious lesions in the anal canal and enlarged pelvic lymph nodes were noted. The patient's Karnofsky performance status is 90.
O: Physical examination revealed mild prostatomegaly and a palpable suspicious nodule in the left prostate lobe with no signs of extracapsular extension. A large ulcerated mass was identified in the dorsal anal canal wall. Colonoscopy confirmed a suspicious lesion extending to the anorectal junction. MRI findings included an infiltrative lesion of the anal canal (3.2 cm in diameter), high-grade suspicion of sphincter infiltration, and enlarged lymphadenopathies in the mesorectum and right internal iliac region (2 cm in diameter each), suspicious for tumor metastases. An area in the left prostate basis showed restricted diffusion and was hypointense on ADC maps but hyperintense on diffusion-weighted maps. Biopsies confirmed poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal and moderately differentiated prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3 + 4). HIV test was negative, and CEA levels were assessed.
A: Primary diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal and moderately differentiated prostate adenocarcinoma. Differential diagnoses include metastatic disease given the enlarged lymph nodes and MRI findings. The prognosis depends on the extent of metastasis and response to treatment.
P: Plan includes referral to oncology for evaluation and management of anal canal and prostate cancers. Initiate discussions regarding chemotherapy and possible radiotherapy options. Schedule regular follow-up appointments for monitoring disease progression and treatment response. Educate the patient on the nature of his diagnoses, treatment options, and importance of regular medical follow-up. Discuss potential side effects of treatments and strategies to manage them. Ensure psychological support is available given the dual cancer diagnosis.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you have been monitored at a neurology clinic and were referred to our clinic due to sustained hemifacial pain on the right side. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct. The pain has been bothering me for a while now.
Doctor: I also noticed that you have been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2. Is it under control?
Patient: Yes, I've been managing it well.
Doctor: That's good to hear. I have reviewed your anterior rhinoscopic and endoscopic nasal examination results, and there were no pathological findings. However, your nasal septum is deviated to the left. Your hematological and biochemical parameters are normal, which is a good sign.
Patient: Oh, okay. So, what's causing the pain then?
Doctor: We performed a paranasal computed tomography (PNCT) imaging, and it revealed concha bullosa variation of the bilateral middle turbinates, and soft tissue density in the right concha bullosa. We then incised the concha bullosa by applying topical anesthesia to your right nasal cavity and performed a punch biopsy.
Patient: Hmm, and what did the pathology report say?
Doctor: The pathology report concluded that there were fungal hyphae and necrobiotic material. So, we prepared you for surgery. After receiving your written consent, we planned an endoscopic sinus surgery under general anesthesia.
Patient: I remember that. How did the surgery go?
Doctor: The surgery went well. We excised the lateral and inferior lamellae of the concha bullosa and submitted the infected material inside for pathologic examination. We controlled the bleeding, and the intervention was finalized.
Patient: That's a relief. What was my post-operative treatment?
Doctor: We prescribed a nasal wash and anti-inflammatory treatment for you. The pathological examination report revealed fungal organisms and their hyphae in the necrobiotic material. An advanced microbiological examination cultured "Aspergillus oryzae" through sequential analysis of the ribosomal DNA genes in the aspirated material.
Patient: So, how am I doing now?
Doctor: During your post-operative 6-month follow-up, we observed that your headache complaints were diminished and your nasal passage was open. It seems like the surgery and treatment have been successful.
Patient: That's great to hear! Thank you so much, doctor.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient reports sustained hemifacial pain on the right side, which has been persistent for a while. The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, which is currently well-managed.
O: The patient's anterior rhinoscopic and endoscopic nasal examinations showed no pathological findings but revealed a deviated nasal septum to the left. Hematological and biochemical parameters are within normal limits. Paranasal computed tomography (PNCT) imaging indicated concha bullosa variation of the bilateral middle turbinates and soft tissue density in the right concha bullosa. A punch biopsy performed after incising the concha bullosa showed fungal hyphae and necrobiotic material. Post-operative findings post endoscopic sinus surgery under general anesthesia were successful with controlled bleeding and removal of infected material.
A: The primary diagnosis is fungal sinusitis, specifically involving Aspergillus oryzae, as confirmed by pathology and advanced microbiological examination. The differential diagnosis initially included other causes of chronic sinusitis and facial pain. The prognosis is good following surgical and medical management.
P: The patient underwent successful endoscopic sinus surgery to remove the infected material and has been prescribed nasal washes and anti-inflammatory treatment. Follow-up at 6 months post-operation showed significant improvement with diminished headache complaints and an open nasal passage. Continued monitoring and management of diabetes mellitus type 2 are recommended, along with regular follow-ups to monitor for any recurrence of sinus issues.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: Actually, I don't have any significant past medical history.
Doctor: Alright. Can you tell me what happened prior to your admission here?
Patient: I'm not sure. I just moved from Puerto Rico three weeks ago, and then I was found unresponsive at home with foamy secretions around my mouth.
Doctor: I see. You were found apneic and pulseless, so the paramedics performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) on you. After prolonged CPR, you had the return of spontaneous circulation and were admitted to the ICU. We started you on therapeutic hypothermia as well.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: Your urine toxicology showed the presence of cocaine, benzodiazepines, and cannabinoids. The most likely cause of your cardiac arrest was thought to be an overdose.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We also initiated antibiotics, vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam, along with vasopressors for septic shock. You were put on mechanical ventilation and intubation for respiratory failure. We have been closely monitoring your laboratory studies.
Patient: Okay, and what happened next?
Doctor: When we discontinued propofol, you remained unresponsive but showed muscle twitching. We performed an Electroencephalogram (EEG) which showed encephalopathy without seizure activity.
Patient: Hmm, that's concerning.
Doctor: On day three, you had repeated episodes of twitching, decerebrate posturing, and eyes rolling, so we restarted propofol. A repeat EEG showed similar results to the prior one. We also did a Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of your brain, which showed diffuse injury and restricted diffusion involving both basal ganglia, bilateral frontal, and occipital cortices.
Patient: That sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is. You continued to have repeated episodes of decerebrate posturing, rhythmic jaw movements, sweating, fever, and tachycardia. Ultimately, we had to perform a tracheostomy and gastrostomy tube placement.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: After a week of initial antibiotic treatment, your sputum cultures grew Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which resolved with a course of gentamicin nebulizers.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: We consulted infectious disease specialists for your repeated fevers. Your blood cultures, sputum cultures, and urine Legionella antigen came back negative.
Patient: So, what could be causing the fevers?
Doctor: We did a urinalysis for infection, checked for decubitus ulcers and rashes, but nothing was identified. Thyroid function tests (TFT) ruled out hyperthyroidism, and an ultrasound of your abdomen showed no signs of acalculous cholecystitis. We also tested you for Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, and performed an interferon-gamma release assay, all of which came back negative.
Patient: I see. What's the plan moving forward?
Doctor: We will continue monitoring your condition closely and provide appropriate treatments as needed. We will also discuss any further steps and follow-up requirements with you and your family.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
ground_truth_soap:
S: The patient, recently moved from Puerto Rico, was found unresponsive at home with foamy secretions around the mouth. The patient has no significant past medical history. The patient reported being unaware of the events leading to hospitalization but was informed about the use of cocaine, benzodiazepines, and cannabinoids prior to the incident.
O: Upon admission, the patient was apneic, pulseless, and underwent prolonged CPR with return of spontaneous circulation. Therapeutic hypothermia was initiated. Urine toxicology was positive for cocaine, benzodiazepines, and cannabinoids. The patient was treated with vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and vasopressors for septic shock, and required mechanical ventilation and intubation. EEG showed encephalopathy without seizure activity. MRI of the brain indicated diffuse injury with restricted diffusion in both basal ganglia, bilateral frontal, and occipital cortices. dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've presented to the ophthalmology clinic today with a complaint of acute onset right eye pain with extra-ocular movement. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've been having right eye periorbital swelling, redness, and my upper right lid is drooping. I've also been experiencing bilateral tearing.
Doctor: I understand. When did these symptoms start?
Patient: They began about 24 hours ago, right after I received my first zoledronic acid infusion for osteoporosis.
Doctor: Thank you for that information. Based on your past medical history, I see that you have chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, Sjogren's syndrome, and systemic lupus erythematosus. You've been on cyclosporine 75 mg daily and monthly belimumab 120 mg/1.5 ml for your rheumatologic conditions for 3 years prior to this presentation, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Let's discuss your ophthalmic exam results. Your best-corrected visual acuity was 20/25–2 in the right eye and 20/25–3 in the left eye. Intraocular pressure was 14 mmHg in the right eye and 13 mmHg in the left eye. The external exam of your right eye showed mild upper lid edema, erythema, ptosis, and a -1 adduction defect. Do you know what a slit lamp examination is?
Patient: I'm not sure, can you explain?
Doctor: Sure, a slit lamp examination allows us to take a closer look at the structures of your eye. In your case, we found conjunctival chemosis, which is swelling of the eye's outer surface, but no issues with the anterior chamber or any flare. Additionally, the posterior segment exam showed that you have posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) in both eyes.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We also attempted 24–2 visual field testing, but it wasn't reliable due to frequent fixation loss caused by your eye pain. Based on your symptoms and history, we ordered a contrast-enhanced MRI which showed ill-defined right orbital soft tissue thickening and enhancement in the retro-orbital intraconal space with extension along the retro-orbital scleral contour and surrounding the anterior optic nerve sheath.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: Considering your rheumatologic history, we initially thought it could be orbital inflammation secondary to your lupus. However, based on the clinical presentation, MRI findings, and the timing of your symptoms in relation to your zoledronic acid infusion, we suspect that your orbital inflammation might be secondary to bisphosphonate therapy.
Patient: Oh, okay. So, what do we do now?
Doctor: We will start you on oral medications to manage the inflammation and monitor your symptoms closely. We will also keep in touch with your rheumatologist to ensure the best course of action for your treatment. If your symptoms worsen or do not improve, please return to the clinic immediately.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.

These symptoms started 24 hours post first zoledronic acid infusion for osteoporosis.
O: On examination, the patient's best-corrected visual acuity was 20/25–2 in the right eye and 20/25–3 in the left eye. Intraocular pressures were 14 mmHg in the right eye and 13 mmHg in the left eye. External examination revealed mild upper lid edema, erythema, ptosis, and a -1 adduction defect in the right eye. Slit lamp examination showed conjunctival chemosis with no anterior chamber flare. Posterior segment exam indicated posterior vitreous detachment in both eyes. MRI of the orbit showed ill-defined right orbital soft tissue thickening and enhancement in the retro-orbital intraconal space with extension along the retro-orbital scleral contour and surrounding the anterior optic nerve sheath.
A: The primary diagnosis is suspected orbital inflammation secondary to bisphosphonate therapy, given the temporal association with zoledronic acid infusion and MRI findings. Differential diagnosis includes orbital inflammation secondary to systemic lupus erythematosus, although less likely due to the specific timing and MRI characteristics.
P: Initiate treatment with oral medications to manage the inflammation. Close monitoring of symptoms is advised, with instructions to return to the clinic if symptoms worsen or do not improve. Coordination with the patient's rheumatologist will be maintained to ensure an integrated approach to managing her underlying conditions and new onset symptoms.

Doctor: Hello, I see you've presented with gradual onset of painless lower limb weakness, paresthesias, and increased urinary frequency for one week. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I've been feeling weak in my legs for the past week, and I've been experiencing some tingling sensations too. I've also noticed that I need to go to the bathroom more frequently.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any recent symptoms of infections, trauma, or accidents?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those.
Doctor: Okay, let's discuss your past medical history. Do you have any family history of significant concern?
Patient: No, my family history is clear.
Doctor: Are you a non-smoker and teetotaler? And have you been exposed to any environmental factors such as industrial chemicals, radiation, heavy metals, or any toxin exposures?
Patient: Yes, I am a non-smoker and teetotaler. I haven't been exposed to any harmful substances like that.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Moving on, you mentioned that you lead an active life and used to live with your partner. Your Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status was 1 before admission. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: On your examination, we found symmetrical lower limb motor weakness in an upper motor neuron pattern with Medical Research Council (MRC) muscle power 4/5 both proximally and distally. We also observed reduced sensations in your lower limbs symmetrically to fine touch, pinprick, temperature, and proprioception, which progressed to significant sensory loss over the next couple of weeks. Your sensory level is slightly below the umbilicus at T11. However, there was no spinal tenderness. Do you have any questions so far?
Patient: No, I understand. Thank you for explaining.
Doctor: Additionally, your deep tendon reflexes in lower limbs were exaggerated with extensor plantar responses. The rest of your general and systemic examination was unremarkable. We conducted blood tests, including full blood count, inflammatory markers, B12, folate, thyroid functions, calcium, liver function test, and myeloma screen, which all came back normal. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis on the second day after admission was also normal with normal protein, glucose, and cytology, etc. Have you had any concerns about these tests?
Patient: No, I'm glad everything was normal.
Doctor: Finally, we evaluated you with a non-contrast MRI spine, which showed focal myelopathic cord signal at the conus and at the level of T10 and T11 vertebrae. The radiological differential diagnosis on MRI includes B12 deficiency, inflammatory, or infection-related causes. We will continue to investigate and monitor your condition closely. It's important that you follow up with us as needed and adhere to any recommendations we provide. Do you have any questions or concerns?
Patient: No, I appreciate all the information. I'll be sure to follow your recommendations. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll continue to work together to manage your symptoms and find the best course of treatment for you. Take care, and please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns.
